story:
Creator of the Project Morriah Aleese Young

ABOUT

Building a World; But Building a World for Women is an installation performance art piece where patrons will be able to explore a handcrafted paradise while taking in spoken word and movement, based around what it means to be a woman. The visual experience will reflect the new world that was built off the wishes of women, but the poetry and choreography will remind you of the world we live in. This project is a tug and pull of what a women’s world is and what it should be.

ABOUT ME

I am a recent graduate of the University of the Arts. On May 10, 2016 I received my Bachelor of Fine Arts in Theatre Arts. While at the University of the Arts I majored in directing, playwriting, and production and minored in musical theatre. I studied an array of arts both within theatre, and outside. I took up courses in producing, stage management, solo performance, poetry, film, dance, and acting. For a short while I studied abroad in London and Tokyo, and I have worked and studied under local Philadelphia award winning directors, actors, and playwrights such as Ozzie Jones, Joanna Settle, James Ijames, and Matt Pfeiffer, etc. One of the things I discovered about myself while at Uarts is that I love bringing art forms together to create an almost undefinable piece. Undefinable to me doesn’t mean without definition, it means the biggest definition you can create. It means to create something so big and so great that the imaginative amount of space it takes up is infinite. I discovered that I often create my strongest work when I unite the arts in an effort to tell a story or curate an experience. By producing my own work, I have the liberty to experiment with multiple art-forms while creating a piece that focuses on important social issues.

PROJECT PHILOSOPHY

My intention is to create a space using pieces that symbolize the way I view a women’s world, or what I think it should be. I am interested in exploring what it means to be a woman, what it means to be a women living in a man’s world, and what type of world women want to live in. With my work I hope to ask questions like, what makes a woman, a woman? If God gave us the power to create our own world what it be? In a day and age where the world is constantly battling issues (and new issues arising) such as women’s rights, social and economic equality for women, transgender rights, cat-calling and sexual abuse, what it means to be a feminist, breastfeeding in public, slut shaming and rape-culture, women who choose to wear make-up and women who don’t, etc. This is a relevant and necessary piece that I not only need to create, but that the world needs to experience. 

PROCESS

In order to create this world, I will interview one-hundred-and-one women, asking them, “What is, what could be, and what should be a women’s world”.  I will then create a world incorporating those answers. You will enter the space and maybe see a cloud completely made of menstrual pads, or a river completely made of hair. While audience members explore the space they will also take in original poetry and choreography that explores what it means to be a woman, and what a women’s world is, and what it should/could be.

WHY $3,000?

My campaign goal of $3,000 allows me to pay the hard working artists included in this project, purchase craft and special effect materials, pay for necessary advertising/ marketing, as well as cover rental costs.

GET INVOLVED

By donating a minimum of $5.00 you can have your voice and vision be a part of this new world. We will send you a survey asking you what should be in this new world? What do you want to see? What do you want to hear? What do you want to experience? When you come to this world you may just see your wish come true. If you donate $10 a personalized Haiku will be sent to you revealing a secret about the world or the process. The more you give, the more you get. Check out the cool perks that we have!

If you’re interested in getting involved in a different way I am always looking for more women to interview. You can schedule an appointment to be interviewed at www.buildingaworld@gmail.com.

We are also always looking for craft donations. If you have unwanted cardboard, paper, paint, string, sparkles, tape, or anything crafty sitting around we would be happy to take it off your hands. Just shoot us an email at the address posted above. We really appreciate any contribution you can make.

CHECK OUT THIS COOL PROMO!

For more information or for cool updates like us on Facebook at Building a World; But Building a world for Women. Check out a promo video for the show by clicking www.youtube.com/watch?v=u5BvhTgD3w0.

Your support and donation is greatly appreciated. Thank You!

Kisses & Colors Morriah Aleese Young or as some call me “Peanut”

The ART-MAKERS

Creator Morriah Aleese Young

Production Manager Christine Maldero

Development Manager Shira Berger

Creative Intern Iman Hanif-Jones

Production Intern Cara Lisa Franz

Development Intern Kirstie Floyd

Development Intern/ Costume Designer Jordan Jones

Director of Photographer/ Editor Emily Angelucci 


To learn more about Morriah go to www.youcantputmeinabox.com

story:
"Once Upon a Poem 2"

The 2nd volume of this project.

A book consisting of emotional Poems & Proses written by Karolina (Skeptical Minds) & illustrated/designed by Helcanen

The Contributions will be used to release min 200 books + the promotion material.
If we reach 2000€, we will print some extra goods just for you.

The RELEASE is foreseen on 21st October 2016, during the Metal Female Voices Fest in Belgium (www.metalfemalevoicesfest.be)

We need your help to make this project concrete. Any contribution will be important.
Have a look to the perks, this time we added extra ones with special & unique rewards.

The Perks:

  • Book perk: pick-up the book at MFVF in October (or any other event), every book will be signed. If this is a gift for another person, let us know the name you wish to see written inside.
  • Cheki perk: the book + an exclusive mini Polaroid of Karolina signed. 
  • Funny Cheki  perk : the book + an exclusive funny mini Polaroid signed. Only 6 available!!!
  • 1 Signing lesson perk: the book + exclusive 30 min signing lesson with Karolina (Skype)
  • 1 Drawing perk: Helcanen will draw a portrait of your choice: you, a singer, a member of your family, or anybody of your choice etc (a good quality picture is needed).
  • Or simply make a donation, as every Euro helps ^_^

If you wish to decide later for the shipping, just send us a message. We will ask you to pay the shipping separately by paypal or bank some weeks before the release, like that you still have time to decide if you pick up your book during an event or not ;)

story:
The Giant Mushrooms are wilting! Heights Landmark needs some TLC.

What a long strange trip it's been! Houston artist Bill Davenport created the Giant Mushroom Forest in 2009 as a temporary installation by Ladybird Lake in Austin, where the 14' concrete mushrooms were the subject of innumerable snapshots, videos,  and even a comic book. In 2010, they migrated to their current home in Houston Heights at 1234 Studewood St.  as the mascot for Urban Harvest's Tiny Mushrooms Community Garden.

 . . .but wind and weather have taken their toll, and the sculpture, meant to last a single year, now needs serious work. You can help keep the Heights weird and re-grow the Giant Mushroom Forest today!

The Mushroom Stone

Your donation will allow Bill Davenport, the original artist, to craft a new, more permanent version the Giant Mushroom Forest on its familiar neighborhood spot, ensuring generations of goofy snapshots from Houston Heights.

Every contributor to the project is automatically part of the Greater Heights Giant Mushroom Club, and will receive a handpainted mushroom stone by Bill Davenport. The bigger the money, the bigger the stone!

story:
OUR MISSION STATEMENT

After Momma Mary was diagnosed with ALS we had an enormous outreach of support which helped us form the Momma Mary Foundation.  The foundation will give back to those in need.  None of our work would be possible without your generous charitable donation.  We are dedicated to creating awareness about the impact caused by this disease and raising enough support to ultimately find a cure. 

ALS FACTS 

ALS Stands for (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis) or commonly known as Lou Gehrig’s Disease.

The disease is known as a progressive, neuromuscular disease that attacks nerve cells and pathways in the brain and spinal cord. 

As many as 30,000 Americans may have the disease at any given time.

ALS occurs throughout the world with no racial or ethnic boundaries and it can strike anyone.

For Further Information You can visit these sites:  

http://www.umassals.com

http://www.alsworldwide.org

http://www.alsa.org

story:
"If you had to describe the HUMAN CANVAS//OPEN BODY::USA TOUR in one word it would be engagement. Anywhere in America. City by city she goes and bonds with its citizens. She tears down the walls of the museum and gallery and allows the public to experience art genuinely and truthfully. And what is that art? It is our time together. The artist becomes the canvas and the public becomes the painter. "


bedhermin.com/humancanvas

story:
www.artistreelive.com

Video is from our most recent show featuring Sha Davis (@shadavismusic)

For more videos check out the IAmLoveReigns channel on www.youtube.com

What is Artis(Tree) Live?

Artis(Tree) Live was birthed from one simple concept: Unity. Created and lead by the artistic vision of poet, mentor, and community activist, Taryn "LoveReigns" Wharwood, Artis(Tree) Live has become one of North Florida's Premier live entertainment and creative experiences.

The Team

Jessica Cherry

Vandy L. Jackson (@vandyjackson)

DJ Bless For The People (@bless904)

Promotional materials by: Ny Connect: (http://theprofessionalsbarbershop.com)

LoveReigns who?

I have performed professionally in Jacksonville, FL and throughout the country for 6 years and through that experience, I have developed a unique love and passion for the arts...not just poetry, all art. Almost 2 years ago, I approached my friend and graphic designer, Benjamin Dodd with an idea. In my head, I saw the vision but had no idea how it would come to pass. I drew a picture on a sticky note and handed it to him. What he birthed from that stickey note became the logo and ultimately the beginning of Artis(Tree)...where love, music, poetry and art reside. I wanted to create a space where artists from all backgrounds could come together and share in the beauty of creativity. Creating, performing, and experiencing it's unpredicatable sight. A feat that seemed to be simplistically complicated at first, but what has happened with Artis(Tree), going on now for almost 2 years, is nothing short of amazing. The infusion of live art, poetry, comedy, music, instrumental, beat boxing, reggae, hip-hop, spoken word, dance and so so much more has made Artis(Tree) Live what it is today and will continue to be.

The very first performer to ever grace an Artis(Tree) stage goes by the name of Goliath Flores (www.goliathflores.com), a ridiculously talented multi-instrumentalist who sang, played an acoustic guitar and tambourines to open up the show. Everyone who was there was left stunned in amazement because during the performance, we also heard a trumpet. We came to realize the trumpet sound we heard was coming from Goliath's mouth, yet it sounded like a real trumpet. I knew then that Artis(Tree) would BE the vision it was intended to be.

 

What We Need & Why we need you

Here are our goals:

  • Incorporate-We are at a point where we are ready to share our experiences with the world. Eventually Artis(Tree) Live will not only be the ultimate live creative entertainment experience, we will also become a platform for dreamers to become visionaries.
  • Diversify-Currently Artis(Tree) Live is based in Jacksonville, FL. We have in the works, opportunities to expand beyond Jacksonville.
  • Give back-In a short time we have been able to donate not only monetarily to local organizations but also by donating our time. We want to do more. We want to give more. Our growth will allow us to be able to help on a larger scale. The very root of our existence is community service.
  • Website-We need to raise a decent amount to be able to develop a professional website and hire a webmaster.

The Impact: Why is this project important???

As an artist, I have been taken advantage of, overlooked, forgotten, undermined, stolen from, lied to, mislead, judged...etc. With Artis(Tree) I have been able to create a stage that has allowed me to no longer have to beg to be heard. I wanted to extend that same courtesy and opportunity to others. Artis(Tree) is a stage where all are welcome and all are on a level playing field. Artis(Tree) isn't about LoveReigns, it is simply about giving a voice to the voiceless.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't help monetarily? If you can, please spread the word about this campaign and about Artis(Tree) in general to everyone you know and tell them that it will be headed their way SOON!!!!!
 
Follow us or LoveReigns:
www.artistreelive.com
Twitter: @ArtisTreeLive
           @iamlovereigns
 
FaceBook: Love Reigns
               Artis(Tree)
 
Instagram: @iamlovereigns

story:
So much art is generated about Veterans, war and the cost of war. This art, both public and private, is usually created by artists who themselves are not veterans of any American conflict. This project will give VOICE to the American veteran regardless of their discharge status, sexual orientation, length of service, branch of service, race, language or national origin.

The project will produce San Francisco's only true public facing art about Veterans and done by Veterans. It will create a dialogue between Veterans and the community-at-large to help facilitate healing and promote the concept of universal peace.

______________________________________________________

"Veterans are the light at the tip of the candle, illuminating the way for the whole nation.

If Veterans can achieve awareness, transformation, understanding and peace, they can share with the rest of society the realities of war.

And they can teach us how to make peace with ourselves and each other, so we never have to use violence to resolve conflicts again"

- Thicht Nhat Hanh

story:
<--Click Me

What the w$#% is Fornicated?

You know how hearing llve music events can make you feel something indescribable?

You know when you want to ask the characters on your favorites series what they're doing next?

You know how the technology in your hand can feel both powerful and overwhelming?  

So do we.

Fornicated links these seemingly disparate feelings. Fornicated starts on your phone, leads you to a theatrical music festival, and takes you beyond with a new community-building app.

We are building a NEW theater. A digital stage. We need your donations to build out the technology.   We have been training invisible performers.  Actors who perform incredibly specific work through a computer and through a texting platform we've built. We have developed the storytelling that leads audience from these interactions to live experiences. The digital stage is not where it ends.  Its where it begins.

Fornicated is an immersive digital and live show.  Its a social-media concept album. Its a nuanced miniseries of music fans that you're inside of.  Its a multi-media marketing campaign. Its a unique web of stories woven through a live music festival.

Fornicated is the dancing sweat of a rock audience, the jolt of adrenaline a text from that person shocks you with, and the held breath of a life-changing theatrical moment. 

Its about the power of live experience amidst a world filled with technology. 

How do I experience this crazy thing?

Right? This is precisely what brings you and us together here on Indiegogo.  

We're a group of New York based artists and producers who have worked in theater, film, and music.  You are someone who we hope to introduce to Fornicated (wherever you are), but for that we need your help.  We want to be in your city.  On your phone.  And at the concerts of your favorite bands.  

We started building the live portion in 2009 to re-imagine the traditional idea of a live rock show. Then we added text messages to your phone. Then we birthed characters living online. And then it exploded. We found ourselves crafting the Livecode that can bring audiences from a digital story to a live music experience.  We've built technologies from scratch.  We've explored the nuances of digital characters becoming live. It has become a whole new extraordinary ballgame.  

However, with each development of Fornicated our audience has exceeded the scale of our technology. So now we have a mission. We want to bring you from your phone to a pulsating-live and ultimately, sustainable community - what we're calling, "a beat." A beat contains the shared experience of a community and band forged through a final concert.  A beat you can continue to connect to through our app.

This is a platform that could truly link live music and technology into a movement.

So why indiegogo? Why now?

Great question! (We are totally on the same wavelength.)  The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council has given us a residency to incubate Fornicated. They too believe that we are on to something.  Our next step involves traveling across the country to research the organizational components of music festivals, meet with technology developers in Silicon Valley to design an app, and put together our own research week in New York City in which we bring specialists in the music, technology, and producing industries to consult with.

This is when we need your help. To make this critical development stage possible.  Company start-up fees, organizational materials, and technology development, add up and we need to take this first step to bring Fornicated larger funding and resources in our next phase.  Your $1 can become $1000 for us tomorrow.  $50 for a tank of gas will power us toward the future of this endevour.  Or even go towards a few hours of programming our cutting edge technology. Think what $100 could do...

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot give, please do share this with your friends who may be interested! 

For additional information or sponsorship information reach out to findthebeat (at) fornicatedfestival (dot) com

Who is Fornicated?

The Fornicated Family has continued to grow.  Over the past two years we have developed this project with four unique bands, over 50 performers, 20 technicians, and at three different locations.  Below is a little about our current Leadership....

Mikhael Tara Garver Creative Director

Former Artistic Director and Co-founder of Uma Productions in Chicago and Artistic Director of The New Ensemble in NYC. Mikhael has a track record of experimenting with emerging forms of audience and performer interaction including the technology-newplay extravaganza Experiment America 2010 & 2012 at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston.  Mikhael has worked alongside multiple musicians as a part of Elastic Revolution Productions.  She was the associate director for Sleep No More in Boston and a consultant in New York. Mikhael was featured in Time Out: Chicago Top 20 People to Watch 2007; one of National Theater of Scotland’s 2009 Emerging Artists and an Artistic Associate of SITI company. She has worked in New York, Chicago, Minneapolis, Boston, Kansas City, Los Angeles, and Philadelphia. She is creating the next phase of ground-breaking immersive theater in the visual art, music, and technology world.  She is the creator and lead visionary behind Fornicated and has led workshops and talks for Transmedia NYC @ Lincoln Center, Punchdrunk Co., SITI Company, and The National Theater of Scotland. 

Will Pickens Digital and Audio Developer

New York based sound designer and self-professed technology junkie, Will has worked with Mikhael extensively and developed a sms texting platform used at Experiment America 2012 and Fornicated from the Beatles. He is the first "texting designer" in theater and is excited to continue developing technology for Fornicated.   He is also the creator of the MegaWatch, a stage management app.  His sound design credits include Broadway productions of Death of a Salesman, Championship Season, Importance of Being Earnest, and Present Laughter.

Gabriel Hainer Evansohn Production Designer

Founder and one of the Artistic Directors of Woodshed Collective, where he is the Resident Production Designer and Production Manager. Gabe has extensive experience in creating immersive physical landscapes and spent five years at the Atlantic Theater Company where he served as Resident Scenic and Lighting Designer.   Credits include Experiment America 2012, Fornicated from the Beatles, The Tenant, Love Machine, The Confidence Man, and Twelve Ophelias.

Tim Gilligan Associate Producer

New York based Producer and Event Consultant.  Tim currently serves as the Associate Producer for the "NYU/Tisch Drama Showcase" and as the Associate Producer of the Brooklyn-basedWoodshed Collective. Other notable immersive projects include Sleep No More (Steward/Special Event Team, NYC), The Tenant (Assistant Stage Manager), and Experiment America 2012 at the Institute of Contemporary Art/Boston. He brings his immersive theatrical perspective and event experience to Bespoke, an immersive event production company.

Katie Fleming Associate Production Designer and Director

Immersive theatre artist whose design and direction work has spanned award winning traditional and experimental theater, film productions, and events.  She has worked at the American Repertory Theater, with Punchdrunk on Sleep No More, at Westport County Playhouse, and at the Institute of Contemporary Art.  She has been a panelist on several immersive theater symposiums.

Jason Gray Platt Lead Writer 

Brooklyn based playwright that has been produced and developed around the country by American Repertory Theater, Actors Theatre of Louisville, Round House Theater, The Institute of Contemporary Art/Boston, P73, Red Bull Theater, Ensemble Studio Theatre, Clubbed Thumb, Abingdon Theatre Company, The Inkwell, The Inconvenience, the Source Festival, and through residencies at The Millay Colony and Djerassi. At Vassar he was awarded the Marilyn Swartz Seven award for best play in 2005, and the Molly Thacher Kazan Memorial Prize for distinction in the theater arts in 2006. He was also the runner-up for the 2007 Princess Grace Award in playwriting and a finalist for the 2011 O’Neill Conference.

Carl Faber Lighting and Systems Designer

Brooklyn based Lighting Designer for theater, music, dance, and immersive projects. Recent: The Tenant (Woodshed Collective), Trouble in Mind (Arena Stage, DC), Wilderness (Berlin), Brother Brother (Theater Freiburg). Associate Lighting/Video Designer: Bon Iver & The National. Resident Installation Lighting Designer & Technical Supervisor for Woodshed Collective, Guest Lecturer & Designer at Crossroads School in Los Angeles, Lighting Supervisor at Williamstown Theatre Festival ('08 & '09). Broadway Assistant Designer: The Book of Mormon, Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson, August: Osage County. Notable Collaborations with Blue Man Group, Obscura Digital, Barneys, Ferragamo, Stanton Collaborative. www.carlfaber.com

And here are more amazing folks who have been a part of the Fornicated Family:  Kai Barker, Joseph Cappelli, Mary Cavett, Jenny Connell, Lyndsay Corbett, Nathan Dame, Arya Davachi, Jeremiah M. Davis, Kobi Davis, Stephen Dobbie, Paul Eddy, Ava Eisenson, Jason Fleitz, Kate Freer, David Fuerst Ackles, Kate Garfield, Andrew Gerle, Mary Guiteras, Sharone Halevy, Mel House, Stephanie Hsu, William Irons, Bethany Kay, Alex Koch, Daniel Kublick, Adam Lebowitz-Lockard, Kyra Miller, Winter Miller, Karsten Otto, Max Pava, Mike Puckett, Seth Reiser, Elizabeth Rich, Brett Robinson, Jake Rubin, Alex Seal, Eric Slater, Beth Stegman, Dave Tennant, Johanna Thelin, Libby Unsworth, Taylor Valentine, Royce Vavreck, Moses Villarama,  Matthew Wilson, Cassie Wooley, Nathan Wright... And of course Apollo Run, The Dirty Gems, The Everyday Visuals, and The Majorleans
story_txt:
<--Click Me
What the w$#% is Fornicated?
You know how hearing llve music events can make you feel something indescribable?
You know when you want to ask the characters on your favorites series what they're doing next?
You know how the technology in your hand can feel both powerful and overwhelming?  
So do we.
Fornicated links these seemingly disparate feelings. Fornicated starts on your phone, leads you to a theatrical music festival, and takes you beyond with a new community-building app.
We are building a NEW theater. A digital stage. We need your donations to build out the technology.   We have been training invisible performers.  Actors who perform incredibly specific work through a computer and through a texting platform we've built. We have developed the storytelling that leads audience from these interactions to live experiences. The digital stage is not where it ends.  Its where it begins.
Fornicated is an immersive digital and live show.  Its a social-media concept album. Its a nuanced miniseries of music fans that you're inside of.  Its a multi-media marketing campaign. Its a unique web of stories woven through a live music festival.
Fornicated is the dancing sweat of a rock audience, the jolt of adrenaline a text from that person shocks you with, and the held breath of a life-changing theatrical moment. 
Its about the power of live experience amidst a world filled with technology. 
How do I experience this crazy thing?
Right? This is precisely what brings you and us together here on Indiegogo.  
We're a group of New York based artists and producers who have worked in theater, film, and music.  You are someone who we hope to introduce to Fornicated (wherever you are), but for that we need your help.  We want to be in your city.  On your phone.  And at the concerts of your favorite bands.  
We started building the live portion in 2009 to re-imagine the traditional idea of a live rock show. Then we added text messages to your phone. Then we birthed characters living online. And then it exploded. We found ourselves crafting the Livecode that can bring audiences from a digital story to a live music experience.  We've built technologies from scratch.  We've explored the nuances of digital characters becoming live. It has become a whole new extraordinary ballgame.  
However, with each development of Fornicated our audience has exceeded the scale of our technology. So now we have a mission. We want to bring you from your phone to a pulsating-live and ultimately, sustainable community - what we're calling, "a beat." A beat contains the shared experience of a community and band forged through a final concert.  A beat you can continue to connect to through our app.
This is a platform that could truly link live music and technology into a movement.
So why indiegogo? Why now?
Great question! (We are totally on the same wavelength.)  The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council has given us a residency to incubate Fornicated. They too believe that we are on to something.  Our next step involves traveling across the country to research the organizational components of music festivals, meet with technology developers in Silicon Valley to design an app, and put together our own research week in New York City in which we bring specialists in the music, technology, and producing industries to consult with.
This is when we need your help. To make this critical development stage possible.  Company start-up fees, organizational materials, and technology development, add up and we need to take this first step to bring Fornicated larger funding and resources in our next phase.  Your $1 can become $1000 for us tomorrow.  $50 for a tank of gas will power us toward the future of this endevour.  Or even go towards a few hours of programming our cutting edge technology. Think what $100 could do...

story:
Hello everyone!

I started playing with clay about a year ago, and in time this hobby sort of grew into me...and I got better. I mostly make fan-art or just custom things people would like to have. Handmade crafts. A lot of people like it and have shown interest in it.

I enjoy what I'm doing, but it's not that cheap. Thus I'd like to show my creations to a wider audience. For that I'd need a web page which i don't know how to make myself. I'd also need to get better tools to work with.

By helping me, you will enable me to get more interest for my accessories/figurines worldwide, and help me make things with better quality.

You can see more of my creations here:

https://picasaweb.google.com/115249505693500330056/Figurines

https://picasaweb.google.com/115249505693500330056/Accessories

 

Why I'm here

So far I was working with toothpicks, so tools would cost me around 30€;

I'd like to set up a web page, for which costs can vary from 300-500€;

Lastly I'd need my own oven to bake my creations (since I moved out, I've been baking at friends place xD), which would be around 150-200€

If I don't reach my goal I'll buy stuff that I can afford with what I'll get - even if I'll only be able to buy new tools, it's very appreciated :)

 

The Impact

My creations are handmade and can be greatly customisable. By contributing, you can get a custom made pendant, set of earrings or even a bigger figurine. The world itself will just get to know another indie artist ^^

Any help will be greatly appreciated, and I hope you will spread the word about my campaign.

Thank you all!

story:
The Inspiration: THE EYEDEA COLLECTIVE.

Eyedea is a project of Hans Emanuel, who brings together a Los Angeles collective of fiction, fashion, graphic, and music artists. From the Box Eight Studio in downtown Los Angeles, we begin our journey with our first fashion art video project: The Black Trilogy. Beyond being a vehicle to explore our different artistic loves, we hope to showcase the natural link between them. Crushing the lines between fiction, fashion, and film is something only possible in fantastic LA—and the result is magic. This is our firm belief. 


This project brings together two ambitious artists: cinematographer Chayse Irvin. Chayse is and up-and-coming DP whose growing list of credits is a testament to his drive.  Director Hans Emanuel is a director and editor who brings his own excitement and desire. www.hansemanuel.com

 

The Vision: THE BLACK TRILOGY

For our first piece, we are exploring a relationship between dark and light, discovering small secret moments of a woman and man. Inspired by the boldest and most inspired fashion photography, we will utilize slow seductive movements that allow us to wash in the beauty of the clothes, make-up, hair, and lighting.

 

The video starts black. With each reverberating click of a camera, a light flash illuminates the scene. We discover the actions of the protagonist to the rhythm of flashes that light up and accelerate as if it were the paparazzi. These moments are stolen ones, each microsecond of illumination defeating blackness for only that moment. Does the woman desire black solitude or does she embrace the voyeuristic thrill of the flashes? The shadows are helpless to our inescapable draw to her captured beauty. We want more. We, the camera, become a character, voyaging to discover more.

 

The Impact: SPREADING OUR VISION

We look forward to bringing our art to the far corners of the earth. The desire to share our art is a primary one. Many of our members were born or raised abroad. We are extremely excited by the wide variety of welcoming hands which will receive our work, displaying it in their exhibitions, galleries, and festivals.


The root of the inspiration for the film, though, is indefinable LA. We look forward to spreading our work in LA in order to spread our vision and get other artists to join in our creations. Opening the doors to a flow of creative collaborative energy.


Box Eight Studio works primarily as a fashion photography space. This is perfect for us and what we want to do. It is the only way to get the dramatic fashion inspired lighting and staging we envision--and it helps to have so many great fashion artists around!


What do we need to make this a reality?
We have the artistic concept locked. All the artists are committed and excited. And from our creative space Box Eight Studio we are in full-force preproduction. Any generous donations go toward securing the costs: 

Equipment rental-Lighting package, camera gear, camera lens package

Production Design-Materials for set construction, set design

Post-Production-Sound design, FX effects

Promotion-Film festivals, marketing, distribution


Our Plan.

We are shooting the weekend of the October 14-16th. After two weeks of postproduction we will begin promoting our work. If we go over budget, then all additional funds go quickly and directly into the next Eyedea production. 


Most importantly, from all the hearts of this creative team, thank you, thank you, thank you, for taking a moment to consider our dreams. Inspired elimination of the boundaries between fiction, fashion, and film means anything is possible—but we cannot escape the restrictions of a budget. Every cent counts toward realizing this project we love!

story:
Hello All,

This project has been started by Shane West and Steve Schack from North Pole, Alaska. We are both currently serving in the U.S. Army. We will be flying to Barrow, Alaska in about two weeks, 28-29 August to do the Polar Bear Plunge in the Arctic Ocean. Barrow is the northern most city in the United States and has the Arctic Ocean as its back yard. The average temp. in Barrow during the summer is only 40 degrees, so you can imagine how cold the water must be. We are trying to raise some money via donation to do this. All proceeds that we make will be donated to the Wounded Warrior Project. The Wounded Warrior Project is a foundation that was established to help military service members who have been wounded in combat, while serving our country and protecting our freedom. We have paid our way up there using frequent flyer miles and no money will be kept for ourselves. I only sent this to a few of you, but if you can pass this on, we would be greatly appreciative! We are not asking for certain amounts or any money at all; we just wanted to get the word out, so if you want to help, it will be going to a great cause. Thanks for your time!

Shane and Steve

“Freedom is never more than one generation from extinction. It must be fought for, protected, and handed on.” President Ronald Reagan

story:
Short Summary

For over a decade the Cherry & Webb Gallery has adorned our city’s downtown as a sphere of influence for local artists, supporting our local businesses and priming the pump of our creative economy. Through no fault of their own the gallery has been forced to close its doors. Walls which once stood as a backdrop for art work to be displayed now stand naked, leaving a whole in the hearts of those who appreciate the arts and understand its importance to any community’s revitalization efforts.

That is where you come in! We would like to invite you to be part of something that is more than just a project: to believe in the importance of the arts, to believe in the importance of culture, to not just our community but every community.

Through your contribution, through your generosity we hope to raise $10,000 to reopen the doors to the Cherry & Webb Art Gallery to once again have a gathering point in our city for our artists to come to and with your help we can make a difference.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Make checks payable to: GFRAA / Cherry & Webb Art Gallery, 80 Belmont Street, Fall River, MA 02720

  • You can also use the Indiegogo share tools to make noise about our campaign.

story:
Hello Everybody!

My name is Jazz Leeb and I am a recent graduate of the Ringling College of Art and Design in Sarasota, FL . Through out my studies I have had the oppertunity to attend the New York Studio Residency Program in Brooklyn,NY and have also been awarded a Student Acheivment Award in Contemporary Sculpture Honorable Mention by the International Sculpture Center in New Jersey.  I currently live and work in beautiful and sunny San Jose, CA. 

I have recently been accepted  into VCU's Summer Studio Program which is a great oppertunity to experience not only one of the top sculpture schools in the country, but is also an oppertunity to engage with other artist, curators, and critics from a variety of disciplines. The experience to be gained from an intensive program such as VCU's is invaluable and transformational for an young artist like myself to be a part of. This opportunity does not come around often, as the program itself only accepts around 10-16 students out of around 250-300 applicants a year ( a statistic given by a former vcu ssp alumni). 

Your contribution to my cause will help me pay to attend the studio intensive program, living cost while in Richmond, VA, and cost of materials while attending the program. 

PROGRAM DESCRIPTION

The Summer Studio Program at Virginia Commonwealth University is a supportive and rigorous residency program with an established track record of inspiring and developing artists within a hothouse environment. Based on our successful MFA program, this 8-week intensive program combines theory and practice through: seminars, studio visits, artist lectures, critiques, professional development and intensive studio time.

For nearly a decade, this groundbreaking program has attracted artists globally to help transform and hone their work and ideas. Participants come together for uninterrupted time to work in generous studios and engage in ongoing dialogue with internationally recognized artists, critics and curators. Hands-on commitment to the advancement of the participants by those leading the program is remarkable: it is what sets this opportunity apart.

This two-month residency is ideal for artists developing a portfolio for application to graduate school, as well as those interested in uninterrupted studio immersion with charged feedback inside a stimulating and supportive atmosphere.

WHAT ALUMNI HAVE TO SAY

Many of the program’s alumni have gone on to some of the most prestigious graduate programs and residencies in the country. Past program alumni have noted:

“In two months, my work improved as much as in three years of university study.”
“Your serious belief in our individual potential and unwavering investment in our art practice was so encouraging, and certainly served as the impetus I needed to begin to transform how, why and to what end I make art.”

“The more time passes, the more I realize the significance this program had (and hopefully will continue to have) on my life as an artist… It is truly a transformative process.”
“I left the program feeling good, with stronger convictions, tougher questions, and more specific goals.”

The VCU SSP Program itself will cost me $5,000 dollars alone just to attend 

Living cost for the 2 months while in Richmond, VA will run me about $1000 

this is why I have set my price goal at the amount of 6,000 dollars.

In order to obtain this goal I have set up a series of perks that range from postcards to posters and even sculptures themselves. Not only do these perks get you great rewards but also enrich my studio practice even more by pushing me to create more work and evolve my studio practice after the program has ended! Please browse them and feel free to contact me with any questions!

all delivery dates for perks are the latest possible times they will be sent out and could even arrive sooner than listed!

The program will end with an art show of all the students in Richmond, Va to show all of the work produced during the program!


Please help by sharing and spreading this to as many people as possible and thank you to everyone for your help! -Jazz

story:
"... You've just got to choose a subject, and what you feel about it, what it means, begins to unfold if you just plain choose a subject and do it enough."

- Diane Arbus
 

David-and-flower-photography 101.

Quick Info and links:  

My explorations in flower photography (link to my blog, opens in a new window) challenge the viewer's (and my) expectations of the subject matter - and  involve subverting the perfection and predictability of digital photography, creating off-balance moments that astonish and delight. 

The exhibit I'm preparing for:

My first solo photographic exhibit opens

February 20th, 2014

and runs until 

March 15, 2014

at

Akasha Art Projects, 511 Church St, Toronto, Canada.


Perks for supporting me: 

Range from 

a personal email of thanks (for a mere $5) to

a COMPLETE portfolio of the work to be shown at the gallery
for a donation of $1,850.  (Galleries have priced and sold individual
works of mine for $2,000).


Now - the whole story.... :

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Real men shoot landscape.  Don't they?

I know.  You've seen it all before.  Quick, what's one of the first things you photograph with the macro setting of your new point-and shoot camera?  A flower, of course!  (In fact, the macro setting is indicated by a flower, I suppose in case you lose your mind and start to shoot, say, a mushroom or a squirrel.)  

And then there are the disparaging remarks.  "Anybody can point their lens at a flower".  (Why, thank you!)  I actually read that online a little while ago.  And although it's true, I'd like to respectfully point out that anyone can point their lens at a mountain, as well. 

It all boils down to that quote at the top, by the great Diane Arbus.  Just plain choose a subject... because the subject is a decoy, a red herring;  it's a sneaky way of telling the world about the real subject: you.


How I started...

(Above:  "Legend", 2013.  David Roddis, Archival pigment print. 30 x 45". Edition of 5.  © David Roddis, 2013.  All rights reserved.)


My initial choice of flowers as subjects grew out of my desire to explore their accessible and dependable emotional appeal as well as their obvious "prettiness".  And, as a beginning (and largely self-taught) photographer at the time, I shot in predictable ways to get the results I understood were acceptable:  "well-composed", "sharp", going for maximum detail and surface appeal.  

Of course, I knew enough to differentiate myself, considering that my goal was to sell my work.  So my motto was, and still is, "go big or go home."  As well, I found unusual subjects - mostly at the north St Lawrence Market on Saturday mornings - and took extra care with production details like lighting and backgrounds to create more than just snapshots.  

But in the end, prettiness became a disadvantage.  I was increasingly dissatisfied and, honestly, bored with the perfection of my subjects and their treatment; and with the tedious predictability of the digital process.  

The digital camera was notably lacking in "happy accidents",  and the only way forward seemed to be bigger, brighter, sharper...  The digital mindset put technique, and by extension, the machine, center stage, prompting ecstatic cries of:  "Such pictures! What an amazing camera you must have!"  But where was art - and the artist - in this scheme?

Creating the unexpected


Above:  "Ante Mortem", 2013.  David Roddis, Archival pigment print. 19 x 13". Edition of 10.  © David Roddis, 2013.  All rights reserved.)


I had always welcomed the flaw in the subject: brown spots, wilting petals; a scar, a bruise, a marauding insect; a reminder that not all was well in the garden.  To this I now added a perverse desire to subvert the very advantage that digital was supposed to bring to the table: a dumbed-down esthetic of technical competence; attainable perfection for all.

I pulled out my glass shooting table, lit it beyond all hope of metering with two flash units, and shot.  I jumped, I swooped, I shook the camera.  I ripped up the flowers.  I broke one strobe and, lacking resources to replace it, instead trained 500 watts of $10 worklight on my abused stars.  I panned with flash, without flash, and when the flash failed, I found art in that, too.  I set up extravagant bouquets to rival the Dutch masters', and let them die in the summer heat.

I was in a state of joyous destruction.  And when I finished each shoot, I had absolutely no idea what to expect.

The resulting images were a revelation. There appeared eruptions of primal energy, gorgeous chaos, where there had been stasis and entropy;  danger where there had been prettiness and order.  I had the first steps of a new way forward.

The rules of my game

One feature of my practice remained, however:  I avoid adding special effects in post-processing.  Once a shoot is complete, my workflow is limited to traditional enhancement techniques such as dodging (brightening highlights) and burning (deepening shadows). Otherwise, any effects you see were there at the moment of shutter release; if there is blur, then the blur was the result of conditions at that moment, not an afterthought.  This is a rule of my game.  My afterthoughts are tidy, fearful; Photography is the light of the moment.

I also allow myself the luxury of compositing in order to create larger works. By this I mean that I have placed two or more shots side by side;  the resulting mural-sized pieces are in the nature of panoramic shots - of landscapes that never existed... 

I also continue to question what constitutes a photograph.  I know this much:  that the qualities sought after generally are possibilities, not requirements.  There is no more need for a photograph to be sharp than there is for a Monet canvas to be sharp (and how absurd that sounds).  Sharpness is an aesthetic quality to be chosen, not a straitjacket to be worn.  

Or, as renowned Canadian photographer and teacher Freeman Patterson has stated, "The correct exposure is the one that you want".

I hope you enjoy seeing some of the exposures that I want.

David Roddis

January, 2014


What I Need & What You Get

What I need from you is help with the high costs of printing - some of which I can do myself on my professional grade Epson printer - and framing - which is NOT something I can do.

I will show the work in two formats:  face-mounted on acrylic, and framed in a "shadow-box" format, in which the unmatted artwork "floats" within a glass-lidded box. I'm very excited to be presenting my work in a new way.  

The other reason for third-party printing is that my work is intended to be viewed at a large scale.  For example, the image just above ("Dahlia Lifecycle") will be shown at approximately 25 x 60", and as an acrylic mount will be stunning.  

Although I'm an experienced printer and I could print the pieces myself, this would limit me to the 17 x 22" maximum size that my Epson printer can handle.  For this first solo exhibit, I long to show my work at the scale I intended.  When I've had the chance to do so before (for example, at a shared exhibit at Rouge Concept Gallery, Toronto, or at a recent fund-raising auction for a local AIDS charity) my work has sold for $2,000 and up.

Funding:  If I don't reach my goal?

My project is running on Indiegogo's "flexible funding" model.  This means that I will receive any amount that is donated, even if it doesn't reach my desired goal of $3500.  

Pricing for printing and framing is steep.  Acrylic mounting for my work will cost at least $600 per piece x 4; printing and shadowbox framing will cost $180 per piece x 10.  

If I don't raise the full amount?  I will still be able to do the show, with smaller and possibly fewer pieces. Not a disaster, but I won't be showing my work the way I intended.

If extra funds are raised, I will use them to produce a printed catalogue of the works in the show.  Any funds remaining will go towards printer ink - a full set for my printer runs to $500 - and then into the "Nikon D800" fund:  my next camera.                                                                                             

The Impact

Ladies and gentlemen, this is a big opportunity for me, and I've got to get it right.  

A group show, a show in a café, a shared exhibit, a fund-raising auction:  Even in these modest settings, my work has been singled out for praise, caused a stir, and, just as importantly, sold.  I've been paying my dues by getting out there and showing my work.  

But this exhibit is a whole new ballgame. The curators for the charity auction saw my work and offered me my first SOLO show at their gallery, Akasha Art Projects, in Toronto (Thanks, Sonja!).  Sonja and Kelly will be working the Rolodex overtime to invite movers and shakers to my exhibit.  


(Above:  "Seven Veils", 2013.  David Roddis, Archival pigment print. 30 x 45". Edition of 10.  © David Roddis, 2013.  All rights reserved.)


Your contribution of whatever amount or whatever involvement (see below) will help me to make a splash.  Believe when I say that I will never forget your gesture of support, whatever it may be.  

Oh, and neat perks include:  Personalized email, regular mail, and video messages of thanks; monoprints ("one-off" reworkings) of pieces in the show; private showing of the work, lunch with yours truly, recognition at different levels, from "Supporter" to "Benefactor", and a COMPLETE portfolio of work in the show.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know that just after the holidays is an awkward time to ask for money!  And I also know that many of us struggle to get by.  Here are some ways to help me that won't cost you a penny - and these suggestions truly WILL help me:

- Go to my Facebook page as listed here in my campaign and "like" it. Invite your friends to like it as well...  There are advantages to getting 100 likes and I'm not there yet.  Help me achieve and exceed that goal.  

- Subscribe to my Wordpress blog, flowerphotography.ca and exchange links with me.

- Follow me on Twitter, (@droddisflowers) and recommend me in Stumbleupon

- Do you know anyone who collects art?  Do you know a gallery owner?  Let them know about my show, send them my links.  

- Do you write for a Toronto publication?  Do you blog?  Do you know a journalist / blogger?  A mention of my show, or a review, is of huge value.  

- Tell your friends about my show, and of course, use the "share" tools that Indiegogo provides right here!

I'm so grateful for the time you've taken to read my pitch.  I welcome your questions and comments, and I promise I'll answer them to the best of my ability in a timely way.  

Thanks again,

David

story:
Help me raise funds for SAVE THE ARCTIC

I'm Glyn Macey, a British artist and serial fundraiser. I'm pretty well known for my work with organisations such as RNLI, National Trust, UNICEF and Greenpeace.

I love to get as many people involved with my projects as possible and over the last 6 years, with the help of many beautiful people around the world I have managed to raise over £70,000 ($100,000) for some great causes.

Well, next up I will be painting my way around the frozen North, and the resulting 100 original studies will be auctioned to help fund the vital work of GREENPEACE - SAVE THE ARCTIC.

This is where I need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

In a nutshell I need to raise £500 ($825) towards travel costs, but more importantly I want to get as many lovely folks involved as possible, it's much more fun for me that way! And in return I have a delectable range of juicy goodies for you including exclusive Limited Edition prints, Original drawings, Books, DVD's and Vouchers.

SAVE THE ARCTIC

My goal is to paint 100 original studies whilst traveling the Arctic, everyone of which will be auctioned to raise funds for the worlds leading environmental charity Greenpeace and their SAVE THE ARCTIC project.

My last trip saw me travel and paint my way across the USA (see the video above), the resulting works raised my friends at UNICEF thousand of pounds helping to fund their vital work with vulnerable children worldwide.

To find out more about me and my work check out www.gullova.co.uk or simply google Glyn Macey

To find out more about the vital work of Greenpeace SAVE THE ARCTIC check www.savethearctic.org

Other Ways You Can Help

If you could share this project with your friends I will love you forever :)

story:
Summary

In 1981, artist and educator Helen Frederick founded Pyramid Atlantic.  Her vision was to create a place where artists could work side by side, share and grow together.  We provide studios with mint condition turn of the century presses, professional instructors steeped in the mediums of papermaking, printmaking and bookmaking and a creative atmosphere that invites experimentation.

Almost 40 years later, Pyramid Atlantic continues to be a workshop for artists and has grown into a center for arts education for people of all ages and abilities and a vibrant center for community engagement. The mission remains the same: to build communities that give life to paper-making, print-making and artists books.

We are a nationally renowned art center that offers competitive artist residencies, programming for youth and public events.  In the last year we provided arts education programming for 251 youth; residencies for 23 artists; studios for 401 artists, internship experiences for 53 high school, college, and graduate students; arts education workshops for 817 adults; events for 735 people, and shared the joy of book arts and printmaking with 500 people through our Biennial Book Arts Fair.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $6,000 to match a gift from The Denbo Family for the  Bev Denbo Artist Fellowship Program.  

Beverly Denbo (1942-2011) was born in New York City and had a love of art from an early age. She earned a degree in art history from the University of Michigan. After moving to Bethesda in the early 1970s, she became actively involved in the Washington Metro area arts community. She got her hands dirty planting trees and flowers as part of Bethesda Evergreen, including serving as President during the early stages of that organization's history. Later, she sat on the Boards of Pyramid Atlantic and other arts organizations, including VisArts, The Round House Theatre, and James Renwick Alliance.

The fellowship was created as a living cultural legacy for Bev.

In order for us to be successful with this campaign, we need to raise $6,000. We know it won't be easy, but with your help we can do it! 

As a small token of our appreciation for your contribution, we have a few perks that we are offering:

    • For a $10 pledge, you will receive a  hand printed art postcard
    • For a $25 pledge, you will receive a screen-printed T-shirt
    • For a $100 pledge, you will receive a mono print on paper 
    • For a $150 pledge, you will receive a two hour print making lesson 
    • For a $300 pledge, you and up to four of your friends will receive a private group lesson on your choice of printmaking techniques (screen or mono printing)
    • For a $1,000 pledge, you will experience six days (or three weekends) with our amazing Artistic Director. You will have the chance to get creative in any of our studios. Lunch is included! 

The Impact

With your help, 7 talented Bev Denbo Artist Fellows will receive:

  • Up to one month of access to a state-of-the-art printshop, paper studio or bindery (specify amount of time & studio(s) needed in application)
  • Key to studios and 24 hour access
  • Ten hours of one-on-one technical assistance or one workshop
  • Storage space and flat file for tools and materials
  • Use of standard shop supplies
  • $500 stipend to be used for travel, housing, materials, etc.

Each applicants will be judged on the artistic merit of his/her work, interest and potential in printmaking, paper arts and book arts (or combination thereof), as well as the quality and clarity of his/her plan for the residency. Artists are expected to give a brief gallery talk about their work during their residency.

Residency Length: minimum 2 weeks, maximum 1 month (artist specify the amount of time in application)

Facilities: Pyramid Atlantic Art Center is the premier community-access printmaking, papermaking and book arts workshop in the region.

Selection Process: A panel of professionals including artists, curators, and arts administrators will jury each round of applications.

Why is this important?

Many of us understand the importance of artist development. We have found that;

  • Artists-particularly emerging and mid-career artists-are constantly challenged with being able to afford uninterrupted time in which to explore new directions in their work. 
  • Critical opportunities for professional development and growth are often lost or delayed due to financial circumstances. 
  • By providing no cost or low cost access to professional studios, mentorship and technical expertise makes a huge difference to an artist of any age or level of experience, particularly young, emerging and mid-career artists.

Your support for the Bev Denbo Artist Fellowship will make artist development possible for 7 talented people.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We realize that everyone is not able to financially contribute to our campaign. We simply ask that if you are unable to contribute, please share our campaign with some folks who can. Many of you have large networks so make some noise about our campaign to your networks and encourage them to contribute!

      Peace, Love, and Print.

      Pyramid Atlantic
story_txt:
Summary In 1981, artist and educator Helen Frederick founded Pyramid Atlantic.  
Her vision was to create a place where artists could work side by side, 
share and grow together.  We provide studios with mint condition turn of the century presses, professional instructors steeped in the mediums of papermaking, printmaking and bookmaking and a creative atmosphere that invites experimentation.
Almost 40 years later, Pyramid Atlantic 
continues to be a workshop for artists and has grown into a center for 
arts education for people of all ages and abilities and a vibrant center
 for community engagement. The mission remains the same: to build 
communities that give life to paper-making, print-making and artists 
books.
We are a nationally renowned art center that offers competitive artist residencies, programming for youth and public events.  In the last year we provided arts education programming for 251 
youth;
residencies for 23 artists; studios for 401 artists, internship 
experiences for
53 high school, college, and graduate students; arts education workshops
 for 817
adults; events for 735 people, and shared the joy of book arts and 
printmaking with 500 people through our Biennial Book Arts Fair.

circumstances.

or level of experience, particularly young, emerging and mid-career artists.

We simply ask that if you are unable to contribute, please share our campaign with some folks who can. Many of you have large networks so make some noise about our campaign to your networks and encourage them to contribute! 
 Peace, Love, and Print. Pyramid Atlantic

story:
Why I want to Travel...


Hello,

My Name is Sarah Rose an I am the owner of a new business called,

~Gypsy Sarah Creations~

https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100004654186281

 Until recently i did not have full awareness and confidence in what my Destiny was leading me to. Now the picture is becoming clear! I hope to use my skills in art, story telling, and connecting/counseling souls to help heal people little by little as we are on the cusp of ushering in the new paradigm within our souls.


~ WE HAVE TO BE THE CHANGE WE WANT TO SEE~

My goals are to:

*Raise funds for a Motorhome we can Travel in. 

  • Raise a Target of 5,000+ Dollars for travel/Art expenses along the way!
  • Travel and Sell artwork/services anywhere we are called to.

I Dare to dream...Ask The Universe how i may serve...and Recieve a way to keep spreading my light with others. I sincerely ask for help in my efforts dear friends. Thank you for your kind consideration. With passion we fly into the future to aide in humanities awakening process : )

Thank you,

Gypsy Sarah

MY WEBSITE WITH MY ART!!! Check it out!!

http://gypsysarahcreations.wix.com/gypsysarahcr...

What We Need & What You Get

Details on the process of my endeavor in co-creation with your support:

  • By helping fund this journey i am trading out my Healing Art in return...
  • According to how much you donate to this cause I will personally commission you a personalized piece of Artwork from ~Gypsy Sarah Creations Studio~
  • Should i reach my fund goal i will use the money to aide in travel expenses  along the way as i spread my artwork around to those who need it. 

The Impact

What accomplishing this mission will do for me and my son is with out end. We look forward to networking and making more connections/ meeting new people and soul family. In the end i hope to help in the efforts many people are trying to do right now like:

  • Unify people with universal spiritual principals/concepts
  • Raise awareness on climate change/ Mother Earth.
  • Heal people with spiritual guidance through personalized art work and card readings guided by heavenly inspiration.

Risks & Challenges

I realize that setting out on a trek of this nature may seem unrealistic but to me it is an expression of my soul. If we were are able to raise the funds for this Trek then so many possibilities will follow for the betterment of many. 

  • I have what it takes because I am highly motivated, gypsy saavy, and aware of  the gifts God has given me to help others. I feel a great sense of purpose here in these times.
  • By daring to make movement i will hone in on making my contribution in the effort to helping unify many people/nations. Welcome to The New Age!!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please Support our Mission by spreading the word! The sooner we are able to set Sail the Better : 

  • This is my destiny...Any donation would help! In turn I hope to give back to you with some of my personalized art work...packed with love and healing messages. Thank you for viewing this campaign in my efforts to raise awareness and bring healing through my Art and messages

In Lak'ech Al  K'in -"I am another you"

"When we begin to live and practice In Lak'ech Ala K'in, a lot of our old ways of doing things will no longer work for us. For instance, we cannot act like victims anymore, and we cannot live out of fear either. We find ourselves no longer preparing for disaster; instead we anticipate a glorious future. It is time for us to rewrite the prophecies. They have become obsolete. The past will become just a bad dream, and the future will become a beautiful vision of which we will create right now." (Source:http://www.alunajoy.com/2007nov.html)

story:
Project Summary

Manitoba artist, Lillian Toews, won the People's Choice Award in the Winnipeg Portrait Prize 2014 with her painting of our amazing choral professor, Dr. Henry Engbrecht. A friend suggested that friends and alumni might be interested in purchasing this painting for our choral rehearsal space (soon to be attached to our new music facilities). 

As the current Director of Choral Studies at the University of Manitoba, it would be an honour to work in a space that had this portrait reminder of the incredible legacy Henry leaves at the U of M... and future generations of choral students need to know about his work.



What We Need

$1600.00 in donations to cover the following:

Artist Fees - $1200.00

Framing and Installation - $400.00


*Any extra funds raised will go into the Henry Engbrecht Graduate Fellowship for graduate choral conducting students at the University of Manitoba (current award holder is Geung Lee).


Perks

Every donation of $15 or more gets you a CD or 2!

*If you prefer to donate for a tax deductible receipt ($25 or more), contact Elroy at elroy_friesen@umanitoba.ca BEFORE making a donation here.



Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Don't forget that you can use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
"Keep ART in your heART!"

I truly enjoy giving back by devoting my time and resources to organizing community art projects. Whether creating art fundraisers for non-profit organizations, organizing art auctions, scheduling artist workshops, organizing artist retreats, or curating community exhibitions... Art projects keep culture alive. Many of my past art projects like the " MSU Artist Lecture Series", Artists 2 Africa", "Baltimore's Unsung", "Con10poraries", "Creative Quarantine", and various other art projects where organized and funded with community support and like minded partners. As we have experienced, more and more of the Arts are being impacked by budget cuts, are either unfunded or simply being shut-down all together. We all have do our part to keep arts in the forefront of our culture and community.  I'm able and willing to offer some of my personal art collections at dealer discounts to further this mission. My focus is to educate and connect through ART.

ART smART...What we gain & what you get!

It's pretty simple. Support my art mission and receive artwork that you have always wanted to add to your art collection. Whether an aspiring art dealer, fundraiser, art collector, art enthusiast or simply to earn extra income, we are sure we have something that will garner your support in exchange for your contributions.

  • Your contributions and support will assist with continuing future art projects. It will also allow me to create a few new projects for 2015.
  • To the right are some of my popular reproductions and original works available as Perks (and I might add, some of the greatest Perks you'll see on Indiegogo!)
  • Funding will be utilized for securing venues, honorariums, event marketing and promotion, organizing art workshops, art lectures and forums. Share.Teach.Create! 

    The Challenges & Risks

    Apathy and ignorance towards the arts kills dreams. Creative beings require an outlet to flurish. We run the risk of raising a generation of deculturalized children at the hands of media, technology and the discontinuance of the arts in public schools. Imagine a world with no dance, theater, literature, music, or art.

    • I have been a professional artist for 36 years. I have witnessed first hand the effects of the lack of art programs in our schools and communities. 
    • Visibility is everything. Accessibility is a solution. Artists have a responsibility to nuture and inspire the next generation of artists.

    What Else Can You Do?

    Understandingly everyone may not be in a position to contribute to such a cause, so you can assist us another way:

    • Help us get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
    • Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

    A SPECIAL THANK YOU TO OUR 60 BACKERS!

    Carolyn Kelly, Cheryl Henry, Linda Tucker, Cynthia James, Loretta B. Byers, Patricia Ann Thomas, Jacqueline Hoskins, David McAdoo, Ed Towles, Fran Ngong, Karen Buster, Cheryl Bowles, Timothy Hamp, Miriam Barrett, Destiny Bennett, Terricios Carr, Nicole Cowling, Lashawn Hill, Everene Johnson-Turner, Patricia Medley, Angela Johnson, Tracy Battle, Chandra Guy, Julia Ficklin, Lea Gilmore, Linda L Gray, Prudence Bushnell-Boyer, Edel N. Alexander, Cecil Flamer, Kenneth L. Thompson, Tina Jolivet, Paul Braswell, Barry Simmons, Ellsworth & Patricia Johnson, Andres Gonzalez, Fay Ashby, Keith Golden, Geraldine Ezigbo, Joyce J. Scott, Enid Basfield, Antonio Mason, Joseph Ford, Perry Sweeper, Rebecca Alban Hoffberger, Shawn Murray Livers, Brianna Faulkner, Jesse Johnson, Betty Entzminger, Toni Trody, Yahna Gibson, Patricia A. Williams, Stacey Parker, Carren Clarke-Mcadoo, Deborah Shedrick, Kibibi Ajanku, and LBH.

story:
Hello!

I am a movement artist, writer, photography dabbler, and alternative carpenter who travels in an 8'x24' mobile, performance dwelling. I move from town to town, create work and perform, while providing a platform for people of diverse skills, passions, and interests. The mobile stage, which transforms from an insular, compact design to an open, public venue, offers a free space for community members to hold discussions, brainstorming sessions, workshops, rehearsals, and/or performances. Each community event is as diverse as the participants. This could look like: someone talking about local organic farming, followed by a mime workshop, followed by a movement study, followed by a discussion on blacksmithing. 

To date Raw Art Tour has performed, organized events, and/or led residencies in:

  • Urbana, Illinois (August 2011)
  • Clarksville, Tennessee (September 2011) 
  • Huntsville, Texas (March 2012) 
  • Urbana, Illinois (April 2012) 
  • Champaign, Illinois (April 2012) 
  • Chicago, Illinois (May 2012) 

Raw Art Tour will be organizing an event at Vandenberg Plaze for ArtPrize September 19 - October 7, in partnership with ADORATION.

 

Immediate Goal  

My immediate fundraising goal of $1,500 will help offset the costs of organizing, marketing/promoting, stage managing, crew work and performing. It will also be used to provide gas while traveling. Once I raise $1,000 from individual sources, I will also be able to apply for grants and fellowships through my fiscal sponsor, which is very exciting! 

If you donate to this project, you get gifts! like:

  • handmade postcards
  • handmade magnets 
  • poetry books
  • personalized surprise! gifts
  • opportunity to rent the stage for an afternoon or evening
  • a special performance for you, your loved ones, or the charity of your choice

 

Why This Is Important

I work incredibly hard to do what I do because I believe it is important work. This is a full time endeavor that I have been financing alone because I believe in the power of open space, artistic exchange, and low-key, no-pressure learning environments. I invite and incite community members to hone their skills, share their insights, and connect with neighbors. These events draw in activists, spiritual communities, tradeswomen, performers, and folks of all kinds who come together and share experiences, dreams, and stories. Almost all of these events are free and open to the public and participants do not pay to use the stage; I believe in free access for everyone. 

Community support from people like you bolsters the success of each event, and furthers Raw Art’s mission. You have the power to connect communities by providing space and time for learning and exchange. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you are not able to financially contribute, but you would like to help:

  • Come to events!
  • Share this campaign!
  • Encourage friends and family to share this campaign!

Please note: if you send me your email address I will invite you to be an admin so that you can use the Indiegogo share tools. 

 

Thank you:)

Sarah Haas/Raw Art

story:
Hello Everyone!

We are from The Savannah Sweet Tease Burlesque Review! Savannah's first official troupe. Combining traditional American Burlesque, with Neo Burlesque, Boylesque, and all other things avant garde. Resident performers Rebel Belle and Erin GO Brahless have teamed up with Miss Cherry Box, searching the city over to find the most unique and awesome babes. Our teases have been hard at work! Praticing for our debut show September 20th at The Jinx, in Savannah, Ga. However, we need your help!

Your Support goes towards...

  * Costumes

  * Props

  * Sets for 8 shows a year

  * Printing of 2014 calendar

  * Tshirts

  * Stickers and other merch

  * A sweet rug! (so we dont have to roll around on dirty bar floors)

With Your Suppport...

  * We will be able to stock our merch that will be available at all of our shows

  * Our 2014 calendar will be available to purchase at our September 20th show

  * Miss Cherry box, will be able to outfit our lovely teases in the best costumes ever

  * We can purchase all the supplies we need to build awesome props and a set for our show

  * We will be able to start generating the funds to produce more shows for you guys

Our Mission for the future..

  * Put a smile on the face everyone that comes out to see us perform

  * To represent Savannah as a premiere troupe for many years to come

  * Produce a traveling show to represent our city through out the southeast, along eastcoast, and beyond

  * We want to send our teases to other burlesque festivals and competitions

 

Help us get a head start!

 

Sincerely,

The Savannah Sweet Tease Burlesque Revue

story:
Calling all LOVERS of live music, theater, performance and dance… 

Inviting ye PURVEYORS of hand made artistic endeavor...

Paging thou PATRONS of the high arts, supporters of horns, drums, and beats of heart, song line, set and setting...

Your ship is in! Come aboard the Serpent Queen for a journey of Ten Thousand Lifetimes…

Our beloved Steamboat, S.S. Serpent Queen is voyaging to Black Rock City for her third year. While she has been a fantastic Playa Cruiser thus far, she has not yet reached her full potential and we hope in 2013 that we will see her thru to the final phase of our extensive redesign.

We have a professional build crew and support team already working diligently on her transformation, and we require modest capital in order to reach perfection.

 

 Some features of her existing fitment:

  • Spacious high elevation top deck with ample space for revelry.
  • Pilot house with observation platform way above the clouds 
  • Dual smokestacks
  • Tastefully appointed decor with period lighting, bells and whistles.
  • Animated rainbow paddle-wheels
  • Baby Grand Piano for Band Leader and or DJ, replete with decks & weighted keyboard
  • 10k high-end sound system, newly procured.

 

 New for 2013:

  • All New top deck with a finished length of 50 feet, totaling 680sf of Space
  • Customized wraparound seating appointed with supple but sturdy oxblood pleather. Comfortable repose for up to 60 people at a time! 
  • Remodeled Pilot-House for the serving of artisanal libations and elixirs, replete with sink, work station, power for blenders, espresso, and tea service. 
  • Expanding the size and fortification of the Pilothouse roof for greater capacity and safety for the observation perch.
  • Installing a brass fireman’s pole for exit over stern to bottom deck to service power station and quick getaway.
  • Installing retractable canvas roof and awning for comfortable, shaded daytime cruising whilst allowing nightly stargazing.
  • Creating a top-deck staging system for live performance, bands, djs, and assorted vaudevillians to plug in and play on with ease and efficiency.
  • Incorporating Flame Effects for our Smoke Stacks that rise 26’ above the Playa surface!
  • Upgrading to dual Biodiesel powered generators (just like our primary engine) making for a cleaner and greener celebration station.
  • Completing and installing second stage of paddle wheel design.
  • Implementing all necessary diagnostics, repairs, and maintenance of our Classic 1968 Gillig 262 Turbo Diesel Coach, the foundation of the venerable S.S. Serpent Queen.   

 

The Serpent Queen is managed by “Roughing It’’, our collective composed of artists, musicians, performers, techs, camera people, and deep-water thinkers based out of the Northern/Southern California latitudes with some members as far away as London, UK. Our core fellowship has been participating on the Playa since 1997. We are in cahoots with Collective Filmworks, The Fractal, Shaka2Ra Studio, El Radio Fantastique, Roy 2000, and members of Fractal Nation. In 2011 we devised the Serpent Queen Project. "Good Enough" isn't proving to be in our vocabulary.  It is time to evolve her form and function, as the Muses intended- as large scale multifaceted 'objet d'arte'.     

Even if you can’t assist financially, please don’t hesitate to contact us on how you can crew up with us.  From the poly-technical to artistic/performance based, our collaborative opportunities are myriad in scope.  All participants will be provided a rich and productive experience through the Noble Disciplines during the greatest festival in the Solar System.

Check out our Facebook page for more information and drop us a line.

A Thousand Thanks for your support!

Sincerely,

JBH

Artistic Director

Roughing It Prods.

https://www.facebook.com/pages/SS-Serpent-Queen/194058260650282

and:

steamboattimemachine@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

Do you write music? Do you play music? Do you want to look like you are a groovy musician when you're hanging out in a coffee shop? 

Then YOU need one of these notebooks! 

I was always looking for the perfect staff paper notebook and never finding it. They are all too big or oddly shaped or heavy... So I designed my own. It's simple, but very functional. It fits in my bag and it's light and coil-bound for easy use on a music stand or desk. I love these books! They are very, very, very, handy... 

Originally, my plan was to have 1000 made and distribute them until they were gone, but then I wouldn't have any more! 

The Perfect Staff Paper Notebooks are 50 pages 8-1/5" x 5-1/5" with a coil binding. 

So, now, my plan is to start my own little tiny publishing company that specializes in these particularly perfect notebooks.  

Composer, pianist, vocalist, educator, and pilot, Kate Kohler is an advocate of fearlessness and music. She is an active composer, performer and recording artist. Before she moved to LA from Montana she composed a series of 3 New Age piano CD’s for her acupuncturist called Lullabies for Grownups.

What We Need 

We need the equipment and supplies to produce these books by hand. 

Equipment:

  • A commerical copy Machine
  • A commercial paper cutter
  • A coil binding machine which includes a multi-hole punch

Supplies: Paper!

  • White, recycled 20 pound sheets for the inside
  • Many colors of card stock for the covers

My current budget looks like this:

  • $1000 - Copy Machine
  • $500 - Paper Cutter
  • $500 - Coil Binding Hole Punch 
  • $500 - Paper Supplies

The Impact

In the future:

  • I will provide these notebooks online and ship them all over the world. I want to be able to keep the retail price at $5 each when you buy 10 at a time. 
  • With this equipment, I will be able to publish other music projects for composers and musicians. Short-run publications with coil-binding, are ideal for music. My brother Rob Kohler's jazz theory book will be the second book hot off of these presses! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute financially to this campaign, but still want to help... I would love for you to spread the word by sharing this page on any of your social networking sites! You'll still get a whole lot of gratitude from me!
