story:
What is Second Street Gallery?

Founded in 1973, Second Street Gallery is the oldest nonprofit (501(c)3) community run contemporary art space in Central Virginia and is now one of the oldest nonprofit galleries in the United States. Established by a group of ten artists affiliated with the University of Virginia and the local community, SSG was the first art space in Downtown Charlottesville and a leader in the revitalization of the Historic District. It is now located inside the City Center for Contemporary Arts building at Water and Second Streets. Completed in 2003, the CCCA also houses two other nonprofit groups, Live Arts (a community theater) and Light House Studio (a youth media organization).

SSG presents 10 to 14 separate exhibitions each year. In addition, SSG presents a full calendar of related educational and outreach activities that complement its exhibition season.

SSG’s primary mission is to enliven Virginia through access to the best in contemporary art and artists and to inspire new ways of thinking, seeing, and doing. We do this through:

PROGRAMMATIC EXCELLENCE: SSG has a 45-year history of exhibiting the very best “art of our time” through the presentation of contemporary art in a professional gallery space, on par with major art galleries in much larger cities.

COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT: SSG provides a resource for those interested in contemporary art and encourages an appreciation of contemporary art and culture by educating the public through exhibitions, lectures, workshops, classes, tours, and publications.

INSTITUTIONAL STEWARDSHIP: SSG has a history of providing the resources and personnel necessary to maintain and promote programmatic and organizational excellence. Our current Executive Director & Curator brings over 14 years’ experience at a highly competitive and successful art gallery in New York City to SSG. The gallery is supported by memberships, donations from the local community, and grants from foundations and the state.

Why We Need to Raise $45,000 for SEASON 45

For the past two years, Second Street Gallery has been the recipient of a generous grant from the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts that assists with funding for our exhibition season and related programming. This year, our multi-year grant is ending, and we are required to take a year off before applying for additional funding. Unfortunately, this leaves an enormous gap in our Season 45 exhibition budget. That’s why we are asking for assistance from you—our community, our neighbors, and our friends—to try to raise at least $45,000 for SEASON 45!

To continue to bring the best of contemporary art and artists to Central Virginia, just as we have for the past 45 years, we need your support for the following:

  • Art Shipping ($11,000): Shipping art is expensive! A large portion of our exhibition costs stems from transporting works of art to Charlottesville from all over the country and the world.
  • Printing ($6,000): Exhibition cards, posters, wall texts, vinyl signage, and graphic design work is necessary for publicizing every SSG show or event.
  • Artist Expenses ($5,000): SSG believes that it is important to support artists, not only through the presentation of their artwork in exhibitions, but also through necessary financial sponsorship. Examples of this support include artist travel, stipends for workshops, and assistance with art production costs (such as framing).
  • Insurance ($5,000): We need to keep our artwork safe, whether in transit or here in the gallery. Artwork insurance is a costly but absolutely necessary expense.
  • Outreach Opportunities ($5,000): Giving back locally is a core part of SSG’s mission, which is why we encourage our exhibiting artists to participate in FREE artist talks and hands-on outreach workshops throughout the community. We partner with organizations such as Charlottesville City Schools and the Boys & Girls Club on these outreach opportunities. Help us keep these workshops and events going!
  • Installation and Packing ($4,000): SSG hires professional art handlers to assist the curator with the installation of each exhibition. This doesn’t just guarantee the safety and integrity of the artwork; it also improves the overall quality of the installation. After each show, the artwork is uninstalled and professionally wrapped with care before being returned to the artists.
  • Lighting ($3,000): SSG has a professional lighting rig that rivals some NYC galleries. But we need to keep the lights on and replace bulbs as needed. This will ensure that each work in our exhibitions is shown in its best light—literally and figuratively!
  • Gallery Maintenance ($2,500): We need to repaint and repair our walls, polish the floors, clean the windows, and keep the gallery looking clean and professional throughout the season.
  • Photography ($2,000): We like to supply our exhibiting artists with professional installation photos from each show. These photos (and by extension, our shows) are also shared online with the rest of the world. We loving sharing photos of our friends and neighbors enjoying art here in the gallery, whether at an exhibition opening, First Friday, or other special event.
  • Public and Community Events ($1,500): We hope you enjoy attending our First Friday opening receptions as much as we love hosting you! Although we do receive generous donations of food and wine for these events, we incur a number of other expenses throughout the year, including ABC licenses, cleaning supplies, paper goods, and ice.

As you can see, a lot goes in to running a gallery and putting on a full season of exhibitions! Our $45,000 goal is only a portion of our overall Operating Budget of $200,000.

If we exceed our goal, we would like to publish exhibition catalogues for a few of our shows this season. We would also love to make a few equipment upgrades (a new iPad, a new database, and a new desktop computer) in the gallery and start planning for our Season 46!

Why Your Support Impacts the Entire Community

By contributing to this campaign to fund our 45th Season of exhibitions, you are helping both the gallery (with shipping, travel, installation, insurance, and other costs), and providing opportunities and support to the artist(s) who exhibit with us. In just the past 5 seasons, Second Street Gallery has:

  • Held 52 exhibitions in our Main and Dové Gallery spaces.
  • Exhibited the work of over 189 artists.
  • Provided the community with over 133  FREE exhibition-related programs, such as workshops, artist talks, and over events.

You are also making a contribution to the arts and culture scene that makes Charlottesville such a great place to live, visit, work, and learn! Thanks to the generosity of some of our community sponsors and talented artists, we are able to offer some exciting perks as part of our $45,000 for SEASON 45 Campaign.
 

Thanks to Our Sponsors

Thanks to the Second Street Gallery artists and sponsors whose donations have made these perks possible:

Bolanle Adeboye, The Bebedero, Carol Barber, Barbie's Burrito Barn, Kristen Chiacchia, Warren Craghead, Tina Curtis, Ducard Vineyards, Stacey Evans, Fleurie, CM Gorey, Sam Gray, Lou Haney, Scott Marzano, The Petit Pois Restaurant, Tomas Rahal/Quality Pie, Madeleine Rhondeau, Joe Sheridan, Splendora's, Kevin Waddell, Tristan Williams, Kristie Wood, Mara Sprafkin, Sarah Boyts Yoder, Paramount Theater, Violet Crown, Eboni Bugg, Common Ground, Ewe Fine Fibers, 20 Paces Cheese, Common Ground, Sarah Cramer Shields, and more!

    Risks and Challenges

    SSG is a lean organization; both our full-time Executive Director/Chief Curator and part-time Outreach Coordinator work tirelessly to make the gallery programs best in class. SSG’s small staff is supported in this effort by active, engaged volunteers and a dedicated working board with diverse skill sets and areas of expertise.

    Second Street Gallery has an incredible year planned for our 2018–2019 season—12 exhibitions and related programming with almost 100 exhibiting artists—but without help we will not be able to execute the season we have planned. We need community support so we can keep or doors open and continue to connect, excite, and educate through artist-led community programming. Your financial contribution to SSG is more important than ever before!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    Help Us Spread the Word! Make your gift go further by considering a few ways of inviting others into this community-based effort:

    • Email 10 of your friends to ask them to join you in giving (in any amount!).
    • Share this opportunity on your social media network of choice. Use the hashtags #SSGindiegogo and #SSG45for45 and tag us: Instagram (@secondstreetgallery) Facebook (SSGCVILLE), and Twitter (@SSGCVILLE).

    THANK YOU!

Photography ($2,000): We like to supply our exhibiting artists with professional installation photos from each show. These photos (and by extension, our shows) are also shared online with the rest of the world. We loving sharing photos of our friends and neighbors enjoying art here in the gallery, whether at an exhibition opening, First Friday, or other special event.

Public and Community Events ($1,500): We hope you enjoy attending our First Friday opening receptions as much as we love hosting you! Although we do receive generous donations of food and wine for these events, we incur a number of other expenses throughout the year, including ABC licenses, cleaning supplies, paper goods, and ice.


As you can see, a lot goes in to running a gallery and putting on a full season of exhibitions! Our $45,000 goal is only a portion of our overall Operating Budget of $200,000.
If we exceed our goal, we would like to publish exhibition catalogues for a few of our shows this season. We would also love to make a few equipment upgrades (a new iPad, a new database, and a new desktop computer) in the gallery and start planning for our Season 46!
Why Your Support Impacts the Entire Community
By contributing to this campaign to fund our 45th Season of exhibitions, you are helping both the gallery (with shipping, travel, installation, insurance, and other costs), and providing opportunities and support to the artist(s) who exhibit with us. In just the past 5 seasons, Second Street Gallery has:

Held 52 exhibitions in our Main and Dové Gallery spaces.
Exhibited the work of over 189 artists.
Provided the community with over 133  FREE exhibition-related programs, such as workshops, artist talks, and over events.

You are also making a contribution to the arts and culture scene that makes Charlottesville such a great place to live, visit, work, and learn! Thanks to the generosity of some of our community sponsors and talented artists, we are able to offer some exciting perks as part of our $45,000 for SEASON 45 Campaign. 
Thanks to Our Sponsors
Thanks to the Second Street Gallery artists and sponsors whose donations have made these perks possible:
Bolanle Adeboye, The Bebedero, Carol Barber, Barbie's Burrito Barn, Kristen Chiacchia, Warren Craghead, Tina Curtis, Ducard Vineyards, Stacey Evans, Fleurie, CM Gorey, Sam Gray, Lou Haney, Scott Marzano, The Petit Pois Restaurant, Tomas Rahal/Quality Pie, Madeleine Rhondeau, Joe Sheridan, Splendora's, Kevin Waddell, Tristan Williams, Kristie Wood, Mara Sprafkin, Sarah Boyts Yoder, Paramount Theater, Violet Crown, Eboni Bugg, Common Ground, Ewe Fine Fibers, 20 Paces Cheese, Common Ground, Sarah Cramer Shields, and more!


Risks and Challenges
SSG is a lean organization; both our full-time Executive Director/Chief Curator and part-time Outreach Coordinator work tirelessly to make the gallery programs best in class. SSG’s small staff is supported in this effort by active, engaged volunteers and a dedicated working board with diverse skill sets and areas of expertise.
Second Street Gallery has an incredible year planned for our 2018–2019 season—12 exhibitions and related programming with almost 100 exhibiting artists—but without help we will not be able to execute the season we have planned. We need community support so we can keep or doors open and continue to connect, excite, and educate through artist-led community programming. Your financial contribution to SSG is more important than ever before!

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
Help Us Spread the Word! Make your gift go further by considering a few ways of inviting others into this community-based effort:

Email 10 of your friends to ask them to join you in giving (in any amount!).
Share this opportunity on your social media network of choice. Use the hashtags #SSGindiegogo and #SSG45for45 and tag us: Instagram (@secondstreetgallery) Facebook (SSGCVILLE), and Twitter (@SSGCVILLE).

THANK YOU!

story:
Who are we?

Founded by Nathan Bales and Colby Damon, DM.Connect is an educational program for young, emerging composers and choreographers. After an application process, three students of each discipline will be picked and paired together to collaborate on a work. Composers will receive lessons, workshop their piece, and have it recorded. Choreographers will be guided through creating a new work to one of the composer’s pieces, as well as workshops on film editing and having their work presented by Pangea Live.

Mission Statement:
DM.Connect’s mission is to provide aspiring young composers and choreographers interdisciplinary collaborative experiences, alongside guidance from active, experienced professionals, towards the end of creating and improving their portfolio of works, while fostering unique skills necessary for a professional career in the arts today.

Vision Statement:
Our vision is to see young artists confidently equipped with the skills and resources necessary to thrive as professionals in the dance and music composition realms.
 

How you can help!

  • By donating you can help us bring these worlds of art together
  • If you can't donate, please share this link and spread the word!

story:
We are so close to our goal. This just added!

THE CAN – For only $10 receive an actual aerosol can used on the mural project, wrapped in the original sketch of our phase 1 Mural. A true piece of our project as a memento and keepsake (Not to mention, it keeps these out of our landfill). Pick up at our event or add $10 shipping to anywhere in the country, $20 worldwide. Click the perk to the right of your screen. This is a standalone reward so it is not included in any previous donation levels. Get yours now and help us reach our goal.

– – – – – – – – – – – –

 

A Quick Background

Thanks to the local community the launch of The Kelsey Theater has been a growing success, and even given birth to what we now call The Lake Park Arts District. That left us wondering, "What else can we do to make Lake Park great?" The answer is to utilize the only real estate we have left in a project that benefits local artists and the community alike.

Where others saw only a blank wall A.J. Brockman and company saw a blank canvas with seemingly endless opportunities. The plan is to turn the backside of the 700 block into a giant mural with contributions from multiple artists. Much like Miami's Wynwood we are taking an otherwise unremarkable alleyway and turning it into a cultural destination.

So why are we raising money? All of the artists involved are professionals, people who make their living from their art. Many times people get artists to do something like this in exchange for "exposure" and as artists ourselves we feel that is not always fair. They deserve compensation for their contribution. So the money raised will first purchase the materials needed and then every remaing cent will go to paying the artists for their work. 

Won't you join us and make Lake Park beautiful again? 

 

What We Need & What You Get

So, we need to fill this wall with eye-popping color that will make The Lake Park Arts District visible from outer space! Okay, maybe that's a bit unrealistic, but we still want to beautify this town with public art. The extent to which the wall gets painted depends on how much money we raise. Here is a quick illustration for those visual learners. 

100% of all the funds raised will be going towards supplies, rental equipment, permitting and actually paying these artists because artwork is WORK. Once we reach our initial goal any additional money raised will be put into escrow and applied to the next round of muralists until we are able to paint the entire 700 building (pretty much a city block). After that, we start again right back at the beginning so there is always fresh imagery to inspire our community.

We are also partnering with local businesses, art stores, construction companies, and the suppliers themselves in order to minimize the amount of money we have to actually spend to make this wall happen. In turn, we are able to put more money into the artist pockets allowing them to continue to share their work and make a living.


Now to the good part… What you get in return for your support! We have a bunch of great perks at all different contribution levels, the majority of which center around "The Back Alley Art Festival" scheduled for January 28, 2017 from 1 PM to 11 PM. This will serve as our official wrap party and unveiling of the finished mural. Food trucks, vendors, craft beer, live music, art demonstrations, and much more will be going down as we put the finishing touches on this masterpiece the day of. Not a local? No problem, many of our perks are easily shipped so you can help support this project from anywhere in the world. At the very least, come party with us at this free event and see what's happening at The Lake Park Arts District for yourself!

 

The Artists

Below are all the approved artists involved in our first round of mural–y goodness. All of which have already submitted sketches and artwork to be approved. These are professionals, artists literally making a living from their craft. We have recruited an All-Star team, Who is your favorite?

Craig McInnis – Born in a small town in Connecticut, June 12th 1972. Music and art runs through his family tree. His Mother is an artist and his grandfather and great Uncles were all big band musicians. Cartoon enthusiast. Foodie. Jokester. Halloween FREAK. Craig cherishes his friends and family. He creates art, for him, with hopes that it will stir something in the viewer…there is no other reason. He creates because he must do so to maintain sanity and relative balance. 

 

Amanda Valdes – As a Miami native, 27, Amanda is a mainstay on the art scene. Her iconic macabre style is instantly recognizable and her impact has spread internationally. Valdes’ art focuses on the female identity, primarily drawing inspiration from the dolls in her head. 

 

Mark "Bulks" – An up-and-coming street artist from Jupiter Florida, his own unique style speaks for itself. A perfect blend of traditional urban train tagging and stylized realism, this kid is the real deal. 

 

EMO – Originally from Union City, New Jersey, Eduardo Mendieta has been living in West Palm Beach, FL for the last 20 years. Starting at a young age he was interested in graffiti and the fine arts. Now at the age of 40 he is showing in various locations throughout South Florida, and being featured in publications such as XS Magazine, City Link Magazine, Palm Beach Times, FreePress Magazine, and Closer Magazine throughout the years of 1997 to 2002. 

 

RIPE – A Florida native that has been artistic his entire life. As a kid, he was always fascinated with "graffiti" and turned that passion into many artistic endeavors. He is now part of many of the infamous South Florida crews he once idolized. 

 

Steven "GROE" Marino –  His bright, bold paintings often depict characters, "the Wisefarmers". These characters represent the conscious found within each of us.  Marino chooses to personify the conscience in order to help bring it to attention, and implore us to cultivate and nurture it. His artistic belief goes hand in hand with his motto GROE, beyond the surface meaning which is to, grow, progress and improve daily, his movement is an acronym for Gain Realization Of Effort. He implies that with the realization of applied effort you can predict your future outcome, and if that outcome is undesired all you must do is reapply your effort. 

 

 

Risks & Challenges

With the success of one of the most-funded campaigns in Indiegogo history in the theater category, so let's just say this is not our first rodeo. We have built an awesome core team of organizers, have city and governmental support, own the building, pulled permits, have artists ready and waiting, not even mother nature can hold us back (we have plenty of rain ponchos for our artists and have even scheduled more than two weeks to create these murals before the big unveiling; even if we are dodging South Florida sun showers). The only thing missing is the money, coffee, and paint thinner to get this mural launched!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to contributions, we really need your help getting the word out. Word of mouth is always the best way for something like this to gain momentum so please take a moment to share this on your Facebook or Twitter. Share this page with your friends and family, tell them why you think it's a great project, and ask for their support.

Together we can make this happen, and feel free to come and check it out for yourself!

story:
About the Project


Noösphere ('noh-uh-sfeer'/noun): "a postulated sphere or stage of evolutionary development dominated by consciousness, the mind, and interpersonal relationships"

The NoöSphere is a spatial audio listening chamber that provides an intimate space for deep thought, reflection, and relaxation. Listeners lounge on a foam-covered floor with a subwoofer-infused headrest, while an icosahedral arrangement of 11 speakers plays pulsing ambient soundscapes. 

The installation will be set up for the first time at Burning Man 2015, far from the noise and chaos of the city. If you find yourself wandering the deep playa at night, or sometimes feel the need to escape from deep house music, this installation is for you.

What Your Gift Will Go Towards:

At this stage, with only several weeks until the festival, almost all of the gear and materials have been acquired. The exterior panels, honeycomb framing, and cross-strut connectors have been cut to shape, and are ready for a test assembly this coming weekend. A few more key items need to be procured, but the main thing that we need help with is the vehicle rental that will be necessary to haul this thing up to Black Rock City.

The estimated cost of renting a 10' box truck is $1500. While we don't expect that all of that can be raised, we're hoping to at least make a dent. In short, all of the money raised through this campaign will help cover the costs of transporting the installation. Everything else is pretty much accounted for. 

So, if you like the idea of lying back on a soft floor, bathed in soft audio, please consider pitching in. Every little bit helps!

story:
The Piski Poker Deck

I am Sheridan James Lunt, an artist living and working in Bristol, England.

I make animations under the name Piski Films, and you can see my work in the video clip above. 

I’ve had a life-long fascination with playing cards and poker decks, and over the years I've made a wonderful personal collection of some curious and beautiful card decks. 

Late last year I designed my own poker deck.


My Dream...

I wanted to make something beautiful and unique, that would celebrate diversity, and would be full of little surprises that reward repeated study.

The finished deck got a great response from those who saw it, and on the advice of friends, I've set up this campaign to get the Piski Poker Deck printed.

I’d like to see it made to the very highest standard, with fine quality print on durable stock that could enjoy a lifetime of card games and handling.


How We Can Make it Real

To do it properly will cost £1,111. This covers the cost printing a quality deck, which must be made in a limited issue of 250 decks (a minimum quantity to make the project cost effective). This figure will also cover shipping, postage and costs of producing the gifts I offer to contributors below. 

Any donation (no matter how small) would be so gratefully received, and you can always help enormously simply by sharing links to this campaign on facebook or twitter. However... 

*a £5 donation secures the contributor an mp3 digital download of my 5 track album 'Kindness', which includes track 'St. James Bell' heard in the campaign video.


*a £10 donation secures the contributor a beautiful limited edition A5 print of the Queen of Clubs, signed with a personal message of thanks AND the digital download of my 5 track album 'Kindness', which includes track 'St. James Bell' heard in the campaign video.


*a £15 donation secures the contributor their own deck, including postage and packing to anywhere. The highest quality Poker Deck, with fine quality print on durable stock that will enjoy a lifetime of card games and handling. Each deck comes in a box signed by the Artist with a personal message of thanks AND a beautiful limited edition A5 print of the Queen of Clubs, AND the digital download of my 5 track album 'Kindness', which includes track 'St. James Bell' heard in the campaign video.

Thank you for your time, and for watching my video. If you'd like to contribute to this project please follow the links, and you can always help enormously simply by sharing links to this campaign.

Thanks again Piski Friends!

story:
Paris: The Art Student's Mecca

A month long learning experience in French art and culture

Who I Am:

My name is Sarah Wylie and I am currently a student at the Kansas City Art Institute. I will graduate in May of this year with a B.F.A. in Fiber, a B.A. in Art History, and a certificate in Community Arts and Service Learning. Although I will be graduating in May and this program is in June, it will still further my education in art history and life experience. Even if an individual has completed a degree, they are never done learning. It is also my hope to attend graduate school for art history in the near future. 

About the Program:

The Faculty Led Travel Program, A Moveable Feast: will be conducted in Paris, France for the month of June. As Ernest Hemingway once wrote to a friend, “If you are lucky enough to have lived in Paris as a young man, then wherever you go for the rest of your life, it stays with you, for Paris is a moveable feast.” Hemingway was one of many American writers, artists, and intellectuals, who felt the pull of “the city of light” and succumbed to its attractions and cosmopolitan environment. In this brief but intensive program, we will explore most of the major sites and museums of Paris with an emphasis on French art and culture. Classes will be conducted on-site in such places as the Louvre, the Centre Pompidou, the Musée d’Orsay, the Musée Carnavalet, Shakespeare & Co., the gothic cathedrals of St. Denis and Notre Dame de Paris. With its many world-class museums, which house objects that span the entire history of art, its abundance of cultural landmarks, its many grand chateaus nearby, Paris has become a pilgrimage site, a Mecca, for any serious student of the visual arts.

What is Needed:

The course I will be taking is ARTHI 3828-01: A Moveable Feast: French Art and Culture with instructor Dr. Reed Anderson for three credit hours. The total cost of the program is $4,095 plus airfare and meals. Through this campaign I hope to about raise half of the funds needed for the program. I am very grateful to have been awarded scholarships, grants, and loans in order to complete my education at the Kansas City Art Institute. I have maintained a GPA higher than needed to keep my scholarships and feel I have also been very responsible with the loan I received through the P.E.O. Sisterhood. I would be grateful and responsible with all contributions to this campaign, large and small. 

What is the Impact:

The first hand experience of standing in front of amazing, historic paintings cannot be reconstructed in a classroom. It is a specifically unique experience to be in person with the artworks I know so well through text and PowerPoint. It is like learning about a person in history class but then meeting them face to face years later and they seem so much more real. Being able to stand in front of many of the artworks I have studied in class has an unquantifiable value to me. Not only will your contribution aid me in my learning experience but you will also be able to choose perks in return.

& Co., the gothic cathedrals of St. Denis and Notre Dame de Paris. With its many world-class museums, which
house objects that span the entire history of art, its abundance of cultural
landmarks, its many grand chateaus nearby, Paris has become a pilgrimage site,
a Mecca, for any serious student of the visual arts.What is Needed:The course I will be taking is ARTHI 3828-01: A Moveable Feast: French
Art and Culture with instructor Dr. Reed Anderson for three credit hours. The total cost of the program is $4,095 plus airfare and meals. Through this campaign I hope to about raise half of the funds needed for the program. I am very grateful to have been awarded scholarships, grants, and loans in order to complete my education at the Kansas City Art Institute. I have maintained a GPA higher than needed to keep my scholarships and feel I have also been very responsible with the loan I received through the P.E.O. Sisterhood. I would be grateful and responsible with all contributions to this campaign, large and small. What is the Impact:The first hand experience of standing in front of amazing, historic paintings cannot be reconstructed in a classroom. It is a specifically unique experience to be in person with the artworks I know so well through text and PowerPoint. It is like learning about a person in history class but then
meeting them face to face years later and they seem so much more real. Being able to stand in front of many of the artworks I have studied in class has an unquantifiable value to me. Not only will your contribution aid me in my learning experience but you will also be able to choose perks in return.

story:
Who I Am:

I am a sculptor who lives in Brooklyn, NY.  I was raised in Naples, NY in the heart of the Finger Lakes, a place which has never stopped informing my work.  I currently work with papier mache and found objects to create skeletal structures which are both familiar and alien.  As an avid naturalist and explorer, I pursue the play between objects and materials left behind, looking for the moment the lines are blurred between organic and inorganic.  A fascination with skeleton and frame propels the imagery of discarded human objects undergoing entropy, and speaks of the delicacy of the ecosystem trying to swallow the litter of mankind.  Bradley Sumrall, Chief Curator of the Ogden Museum of Southern Art, has described my work as being “...surreal, masterfully crafted, organic curiosities - fetish objects from a cult of decay.”


The Project:

I will be in Hilmsen, Germany for four weeks.  There, I’ll begin a new series of skull and bone sculptures using bronze and found materials.  My goal is to complete three to four new pieces.  As an emerging artist, this is an enormous opportunity for me. I will be working in a foundry one-on-one with a master caster to create unique pieces in a new material.  


Why I Need Your Help:

The money raised in this campaign will be used to offset travel and shipping expenses.  Airfare is around $1400, and shipping will be significant due to the weight of the material.  Any level of help is deeply appreciated.

story:
Hello,

I’m Maax.

Half of my life I was working with children, learning, teaching and doing a lot of stuff together. Maybe this is why I like toys, any types of toys, handmade and retail ones, plastic, wood or rubber, action figures, minifigures, collectible sets, designer vinyl, and custom toys. Some time ago I’ve got an idea to make my own do-it-yourself platform, blank toy.  

I did several sketches on paper, few designs, until this little creature came to mind.

                                                        ***EUREKA***  

Hmmm… do you know why we use a light bulb to illustrate an idea?


Introducing Lumi!

Lumi is a modern mystical or magical creature, light spirit, body of light that simply brings ideas to you. So if you need ideas just grab it and keep it closer. Empower it with your own touch. Do you know already how your personal Lumi will look like?

For true unbelievers, those who don’t believe in fairytales or particularly in this storyline:  

Lumi is a do-it-yourself platform toy, designed on paper (high technologies free), hand sculpted (non 3D modeling product) and hand casted in plastic.




  •                 Head in the shape of a light bulb – here the ideas come from.   
  •                 Articulated arms.
  •                Lumi body - compatible to lightbulbs with E27 socle, so you can easily                  use a lightbulb instead of its head. 
  •               Hight:    135mm (  5,3" )

Give it your own unique design, draw on it, paint, modify, cut or drill or leave it as it is. Have fun.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Download LUMI template from the gallery --> Draw your design on this template --> Post it on Instagram with hashtag #lumicontest and @mxmilian --> Be ready to win and receive LUMI DIY! 
Help spread the word about LUMI Contest reposting this on facebook & instagram
I'll post all best creations here in the gallery and blog, shoutout on my instagram, and facebook page.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Where will the funds go

Your help and support will go for the first run of in-house production!

1.            Buying materials for molds and casting

2.           Equipment and tools

3.           Shipping costs

4.           Also I’m planning to take part at the first COMICCON Russia which will be                held in Moscow this autumn. And I will prepare some toys and get ready for it.



Здравствуйте,

Меня зовут Макс, по паспорту действительно Максимилиан. Большую часть своей жизни я работаю с детьми, вероятно, здесь кроется мое увлечение игрушками. Некоторое время назад, у меня появилась идея сделать свою собственную дизайнерскую игрушку D.I.Y. платформу.  Много времени ушло на подготовку, менял дизайн… пока это маленькое существо не появилось на свет.

LUMI– волшебное создание, которое вдохновляет и порождает идеи. Может принимать любой облик. А в каком образе LUMI приходит к вам, выбор за вами.


                  ЧТО ЖЕ ТАКОЕ LUMI ???

                  Это фигурка - талисман, которую раскрашивают. Люми - дизайнерская                           игрушка белого цвета, высотой 13 см. Модель сделана вручную и в                                 дальнейшем вручную отливается из пластика.


Я собираю средства для выпуска первой серии LUMI. Необходимо закупить оптом материалы для изготовления и литья форм, дополнительное оборудование, сопутствующие расходные материалы.

Цель!

Выпуск дизайнерской D.I.Y. игрушки, созданной и производимой в России, доступной и узнаваемой. Развитие дизайнерской виниловой игрушки как направления в России.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Сохрани макет - контур Люми из галереи --> Придумай и нарисуй своего Люми на этом макете --> Выложи эскиз в Instagram с тэгом #lumicontest и @mxmilian --> Готовься к выигрышу фигурки Люми!

Помогите распространить информацию об этом конкурсе, участвовать могут все, взрослые и дети, друзья и знакомые. Разместите этот рисунок выше у себя в Facebook и Instagram.

Лучшие эскизы я опубликую здесь и в блоге, в своем instagram и facebook. Победитель получит белую фигурку Люми, для реализации своей идеи! 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Perks for Backers




     

  

   

 


  • Если вам интересен данный проект, то вы можете поддержать его своим участием в лотерее. За $3 вы получаете шанс выиграть одну белую фигурку LUMI. Количество победителей будет зависеть от числа участников. Каждый вклад важен!
  • За $21 вы можете приютить LUMIи забрать его в Москве в октябре.
  • Первые и самые смелые поддержавшие получают LUMI за $27, доставка включена и LUMI отправится к вам, где бы вы ни находились! 
  • Одна белая игрушка LUMI за $33. Доставка включена.     
  • LUMI который светится в темноте (флюоресцентный) $40. Обладает суперсилой - может приносить идеи даже по ночам!      
  • Не можете решить какой LUMI вам нравится больше - две фигурки LUMI одна белая и одна светящаяся в темноте, всего за $66. Доставка включена.    
  • Три головы лучше чем одна. Три LUMI по цене $85, можно подарить друзьям или воплотить сразу несколько идей. Доставка включена.     
  • Большой набор - 10 LUMI за $240        

ЧТО ТАКОЕ ИГРУШКА D.I.Y

D.I.Y.  (от английского Do-it-yourselfсделай это сам). В нескольких словах, если мы говорим об игрушках, то D.I.Y. это фигурка для раскрашивания. К примеру, на Руси расписывали матрешки, в современном мире используют виниловые, пластиковые фигурки разнообразных форм, как основу для воплощения своих идей. Такие игрушки-фигурки можно раскрашивать карандашами, маркерами, красками, их можно видоизменять, резать, пилить, сверлить, приклеивать или лепить дополнительные детали. Такие работы становятся авторскими, уникальными произведениями искусства. Игрушки превращаются в героев разных культур, кино, мультфильмов и комиксов, а также в существующих или вымышленных персонажей, невиданных существ от милых и добрых до страшных и ужасных.

Наверное, многие рисовали на бумаге, доске для мела, стене или асфальте. Так вот дизайнерские игрушки – рисование на объемных поверхностях.  

Узнать больше можно на http://vinyltoys.kz/wiki/index.php


Project Development:

  1. Design  (Done)
  2.     Sculpting  (Done)
  3.         Material tests  (Done)
  4.             Prototypes  (Done)
  5.                 Finalizing the master model  (97%)
  6.                      Ordering materials
  7.                           Mold making
  8.                                Production / hand casting
  9.                                     Shipping

After the end of IndieGoGo campaign I will start to produce toys and by mid october I will arrange shipping. It takes approximately a month to deliver a package  from Russia to most countries. 


FEATURED IN:

   

        

 


           




Thank YOU!

I would like to thank every backer for any contribution and any kind of support. I'm glad to become a part of IndieGoGo community and very thankful to Indiegogo for this opportunity. Please share this project through Facebook, Twitter, Instagram. Any help is appreciated, spread the word. You make it real.  

Feel free to find me on Facebook, or write me any questions via e-mail.

Instagram: @mxmilian 

e-mail: mxmilian@me.com

Check out for news and updates, join the contest to win a toy. I'm open for any communication and new contacts.


Special thanks to:

  • Lena - film maker
  • Film location - Zelenaya shkola of Gorky Park, Moscow                                                     - http://www.park-gorkogo.com/kids/greenschool/
  • Music: "Crazy Glue instrumental" by Josh Woodward - http://www.joshwoodward.com/

story:
From youth through 75 years I have devoted my life to - THE ARTS - as a dancer, painter oil on canvas and silk, and ceramics. "SILK" brings my over 40 years of silk work into a beautiful comprehensive form for friends, other artists, and the world to enjoy.

I have been informed that it will cost approximately $3,000 USD to produce.

The book is already in outline form and ready to proceed. 

If I don't reach the goal, the funds raised will still go to the book's production.

WEBSITE:

http://www.richardzelens.weebly.com

See Gallery for sample images.

Resume:

Born   Dubuque, Iowa    November 19 1939

1959 -1966  Danced professionally with Robert Joffrey Ballet, Metropolitan Opera Ballet, Nederlands Dans Theatre, American Ballet Theater plus several New York avante-guard dance companies.

1966-69 studied art at Cooper Union, New York City and worked at The Museum of Modern Art, NYC.

1968 -2005 produced hand painted fabric for leading New York interior decorators, fashion designer Halston, and kimono for Bergdorf Goodman under my own label.

1978  Beginning Sphere, an instillation of 42 hand painted banners based on Tibetan Buddhist teaching.  Each panel  14’ x 4’  112  Workshop, 112 Green St. Soho, New York City

1779 First Steps a solo dance concert given at the Merce Cunningham Studios. Sets, costume, choreography and danced by me.  

1980 Les Dances   choreographed, sets and costume and danced in it for a small New York dance company.

1983 Moved to Woodstock, New York where I owned my creative studio, renting it for classes in various art related subjects.  I was very active in the local art scene with several local gallery exhibitions.

1996 produced a Bucolic Hudson Valley mural in Kingston, New York                       40” x 60’ on an outside brick wall.

1997 on the board of the Pauline Oliveros Foundation, had a retrospective exhibit there.

1999 moved to Tucson, AZ. where I purchased a large property which became my studios and my gallery;   Gallery 410;   showing local artists.  2000-2005

2005 purchased a new studio/home where I continue to produce oil paintings, ceramics and hand painted silks.

2010 Won a cash grant from The Haven Foundation 

2011 Painting   Ever Day Saints shown at  The Tucson Museum of Art Biennial

2014 continues painting silk, oil on canvas, and ceramics


This is the outline of SILK:


SILK

Black Kimono


Silk in white script     maroon ground

Information pages

Dedicated to 

Ace

In the right place 

at the right time


plus other friends whose support 

has been constant


                                                                                                                      1 

 image                                                                                                                                     

a sample first silk presented 

____________________________________________________________

                                                                                                                         2


Beginnings


Having been taught to play with batik painting on fabric, my friend Alan Campbell……not the Dorothy Parker one……
and I continued to play on.
Alan, being  well situated socially and closet of friends with Sister Parish and Albert Hadley
…two of New York’s LEADING decorators
gave them gifts of our batik play.
They loved ‘em and decided to give us a show in their office.
Although novices, off we were on a lucrative business painting upholstery fabric for leading NY decorators with hot bees wax and dyes
....if ever I should come down with sever lung problems, blame it on
years inhaling beeswax fumes 

images    chair, pillows

_____________________________________________________________

                                                                                                          3

image.....me painting 90 yard of flame stitch

        Some Fords
         ….I believe
         in Gross Point
         ….I believe
         ordered a set a flame stitch drapery for their dinning room
        Redecorating they couldn’t find fabric they liked to replace the
        first set so order two sets to be safe
        90 yards of flame stitch

                                                                                                              4

Alan Campbell Incorporated
We had a great me designing his first line

HALSTON

In society circles, Alan was acquainted with Halston, a leading fashion designer. We ended up painting kaftans or him.
Me slaving away in Sag Harbor, Alan delivering the goods
As with many things, it ran its course.
I was replaced by a Halston friend

Unfortunately no images available

BERGDORF GOODMAN

Searching again for needed work, I approached Bill Tice

Fortunately Bergdorf Goodman offered him  2, 5th ave. Holiday windows

Bill, searching for window ideas commissioned me to paint a kimono which he presented to BG.  
They loved it
12 kimono ordered 
produce in 12 weeks

image Sample kimono

…….Vogue Stivaros drawing?                                                          ____________________________________________________________

….no credit given me

At This point I was working directly with the buyer at BG. Who offered two 58th. St. windows with my own label

AT HOME WITH RICHARD ZELENS

Images

New Holiday windows planned
Very expensive French jacquard was order

Not successful
The coned mannequins did nothing alluring to the pieces
I was told later some were stolen??????

My buyer had left
The new one not interested in promoting me
working in my small studio apartment  in Washington Heights on 181st  St.
not part of the fashion world

_____________________________________________________________

                                                                                                                    24

By this time I was on the road to Woodstock New York setting up my studios for painting, ceramics and silk.

PEACE BANNER

Friend Tonia S. arranged a commission to produce 20 panels for 
A peace rally

20 panels   4’ x 9’

Images pages  25 26 27 28

commissioned me to produce 14 banners for their dining room

                                                                                                               31/32

Woodstock

I moved to Woodstock in’82
Slowly the NY connection dissolved.  I continued experimenting with silk ideas
Not having a couture seamstress made things difficult so few fashion pieces were completed.

images 

Coats, bomber jackets, men’s coats      33 34 35……

_____________________________________________________________


TUCSON

In “99 a spur of folly moved me cross country to Tucson, Arizona
silk exploration continued, again not having a couture seamstress to sew my productions, I mainly work with 44” x 72” silk pieces

A good sized canvas to play on
Good as shawls, scarves, sarong and hangings
Or cut and sewn into garments

Images    8 Geometric, 2 banners,   25 Floral,  2 Tigers. Aida, 1 Hung panel…a Tibetan image  
many pages


The play continues on…….

story_txt:
From youth through 75 years I have devoted my life to - THE ARTS - as a dancer, painter oil on canvas and silk, and ceramics. "SILK" brings my over 40 years of silk work into a beautiful comprehensive form for friends, other artists, and the world to enjoy.

I have been informed that it will cost approximately $3,000 USD to produce.
The book is already in outline form and ready to proceed. 
If I don't reach the goal, the funds raised will still go to the book's production.
WEBSITE:
http://www.richardzelens.weebly.com
See Gallery for sample images.
Resume:


Born   Dubuque, Iowa    November 19 1939
1959 -1966  Danced professionally with Robert Joffrey Ballet, Metropolitan Opera Ballet, Nederlands Dans Theatre, American Ballet Theater plus several New York avante-guard dance companies.
1966-69 studied art at Cooper Union, New York City and worked at The Museum of Modern Art, NYC.
1968 -2005 produced hand painted fabric for leading New York interior decorators, fashion designer Halston, and kimono for Bergdorf Goodman under my own label.
1978  Beginning Sphere, an instillation of 42 hand painted banners based on Tibetan Buddhist teaching.  Each panel  14’ x 4’  112  Workshop, 112 Green St. Soho, New York City
1779 First Steps a solo dance concert given at the Merce Cunningham Studios. Sets, costume, choreography and danced by me.  
1980 Les Dances   choreographed, sets and costume and danced in it for a small New York dance company.
1983 Moved to Woodstock, New York where I owned my creative studio, renting it for classes in various art related subjects.  I was very active in the local art scene with several local gallery exhibitions.
1996 produced a Bucolic Hudson Valley mural in Kingston, New York                       40” x 60’ on an outside brick wall.
1997 on the board of the Pauline Oliveros Foundation, had a retrospective exhibit there.
1999 moved to Tucson, AZ. where I purchased a large property which became my studios and my gallery;   Gallery 410;   showing local artists.  2000-2005
2005 purchased a new studio/home where I continue to produce oil paintings, ceramics and hand painted silks.
2010 Won a cash grant from The Haven Foundation 
2011 Painting   Ever Day Saints shown at  The Tucson Museum of Art Biennial
2014 continues painting silk, oil on canvas, and ceramics

This is the outline of SILK:


SILK
Black Kimono

Silk in white script     maroon ground
Information pages
Dedicated to 
Ace
In the right place 
at the right time

plus other friends whose support 
has been constant

story:
Taller de Arte El Refugio - The Refuge Art Studio - created by Emily K. Grieves

My artistic vision: The desire and the opportunity to create artwork has been one of the greatest gifts in my life. Art has saved me many times over, allowing me shelter in times of darkness and blessing me with a way for joyous expression in times of light. The creative process for me has always been linked to inquiry into life’s meaning and purpose, and has taken me into realms of understanding and inner knowledge I never could have imagined had I not chosen to walk the art-making path.  While my intention with my art-making is to create beauty in the world, that does not necessarily mean making a pretty picture. Rather it means developing my imagination and intuition and opening the eyes of my interior vision to see the world as beautiful, to experience life as beautiful, to discover a way into beauty and harmony and peace by shifting perspective and looking for light in all the dark places.

Bringing the vision to the people of Teotihuacan: Because people ask me all the time about my artwork and the vision behind it, I recognized a need here in my community in Teotihuacan to provide this type of experience in a guided studio setting.  Women and girls in particular have expressed a need for a comfortable safe space in which to explore their own imagination in a positive way, perhaps for the first time in their lives, and so it is my intention to make that space available for them with gentle guided visioning resulting in creating a painting following transformative step by step instruction.  I am developing a small commercial storefront we have available into an art studio that will provide shelter and refuge from the storms of life, where people can come and relax into their interior worlds for a couple hours, enjoy playing with color and shape and texture, and learn how to tune into their own connection to the source of their inspiration. This space will be called “Taller de Arte El Refugio” … which translates to English as The Refuge Art Studio. This year I will complete training as an Intentional Creativity Coach and Intuitive Painting teacher in the Color of Woman method developed by Shiloh Sophia McCloud, and I'm excited to be able to offer this deeply healing creative process to the people here. 

How you can help: Thankfully I can provide this opportunity for a fairly minimal cost to students, but I need your help to make it happen.  My immediate needs are for basic things like a glass front sliding door, lighting, plumbing repairs, easels, shelving units, tables and chairs, and basic communal art supplies. We are seeking donations to help cover the costs of these items.  My goal is to begin the first class on Sept. 22, so I'm working hard to make the place look beautiful and inspiring soon! Your generous donation to bringing art and consciousness opportunities to the local population of Teotihuacan is deeply appreciated with heart-felt gratitude! 

To find out more about Emily and her art, please visit:  www.EmilyKGrievesArt.com

of understanding and inner knowledge I never could have imagined had I not
chosen to walk the art-making path.  While
my intention with my art-making is to create beauty in the world, that does not
necessarily mean making a pretty picture. Rather it means developing my
imagination and intuition and opening the eyes of my interior vision to see the
world as beautiful, to experience life as beautiful, to discover a way into
beauty and harmony and peace by shifting perspective and looking for light in
all the dark places. 
Bringing the vision to the people of Teotihuacan: Because people ask me all the time about my artwork and the
vision behind it, I recognized a need here in my community in Teotihuacan to
provide this type of experience in a guided studio setting.  Women and girls in particular have expressed
a need for a comfortable safe space in which to explore their own imagination
in a positive way, perhaps for the first time in their lives, and so it is my
intention to make that space available for them with gentle guided visioning
resulting in creating a painting following transformative step by step
instruction.  I am developing a small
commercial storefront we have available into an art studio that will provide
shelter and refuge from the storms of life, where people can come and relax
into their interior worlds for a couple hours, enjoy playing with color and
shape and texture, and learn how to tune into their own connection to the
source of their inspiration. This space will be called “Taller de Arte El
Refugio” … which translates to English as The Refuge Art Studio. This year I will complete training as an Intentional Creativity Coach and Intuitive Painting teacher in the Color of Woman method developed by Shiloh Sophia McCloud, and I'm excited to be able to offer this deeply healing creative process to the people here. 
How you can help: Thankfully I can provide this opportunity for a fairly minimal cost
to students, but I need your help to make it happen.  My immediate needs are for basic things like
a glass front sliding door, lighting, plumbing repairs, easels, shelving units,
tables and chairs, and basic communal art supplies. We are seeking donations to help cover the costs of these items.  My goal is to begin the first class on Sept. 22, so I'm working hard to make the place look beautiful and inspiring soon! Your generous donation to bringing art and consciousness opportunities
to the local population of Teotihuacan is deeply appreciated with heart-felt
gratitude! To find out more about Emily and her art, please visit:  www.EmilyKGrievesArt.com

story:
Hey there! I'm Noella Whitney, and illustrator and aspiring Buff Lady!


I've always had an appreciation for strong, muscular girls, and I realized that there isn't much content dedicated to them (or even a female equivalent of the term "bara")! What a better way to appreciate them than by getting a whole bunch of artists and writers together to make a tribute??

Heiresses of Atalanta - The Buff Babes Zine is 40+ full-color pages of rad art and writing by 30+ artists from around the world about this subset of awesome women! Heck yeah!!

The artists and writers participating are Yokaiy, Camila Fortuna (Gunkiss), skipthesubway, Amanda J. Ellis, Gabriela Camarillo Gil, Laura R., Karli Cooper (mosaur), Ashley Ribblett, Sharon Sun (Laitma), Choco, Marta Milczarek, Maureen Tanafon, K.Lee Kain, Rontra, Jonne Bartelds, Sam Boyd (inverts), Federico Iglesias, Lani Goto, Cécile J (Zellk), Sharkbomb, C.Jones (Tintostudio), Eva Anner,Les Valiant, Devonition, Judge Anon, Meggie Man, Dani Romero (Dis), Laura Lee, Sintija Ukše (siins), Stefanie Battalene, Rebecca George, Susan Knowles (Sooz) and Noella Whitney!

What We Need

All funds raised will go towards printing and shipping of the zine and the limited edition print! Each participating artist will also receive a free copy for their hard work.

What You Get

  • $1 USD will get you my utmost thanks and a digital bone-crushin' hug!
  • $5 USD will get you a PDF of the zine sent to your e-mail!
  • $13 USD / $16 USD (USA+Canada / Other International) will get you a physical copy mailed to your doorstep!
  • $22 will get you TWO printed zines in the mail, one for you and one to share!!
  • $25 will get you the physical zine, plus a LIMITED EDITION print of a Buff Lady, illustrated by Karli Cooper (mosaur)!
  • $35 will get you the zine in both printed and PDF form, PLUS 2 randomly chosen exclusive 5.5 in x 8.5 in prints illustrated by Karli Cooper (mosaur), Federico Iglesias, Sharkbomb, Rebecca George, C.Jones (Tintostudio), and Amanda J. Ellis, AND one of two 2 in x 2 in stickers of a Buff Lady illustrated by Sintija Ukše (siins) and Sam Boyd (inverts)! 
  • $65 will get you the zine in both printed and PDF form, ALL of the exclusive 5.5 in x 8.5 in prints illustrated by Karli Cooper (mosaur), Federico Iglesias, Sharkbomb, Rebecca George, C.Jones (Tintostudio), and Amanda J. Ellis, and BOTH 2 in x 2 in stickers of Buff Ladies illustrated by Sintija Ukše (siins) and Sam Boyd (inverts)!
  • $75 will get the zine in both print and PDF form, BOTH buff lady stickers illustrated by Sintija Ukše (siins) and Sam Boyd (inverts), AND a framed 8 in x 10 in watercolor and ink commission by Dani Romero (Dis)!


Prints and Stickers

By Sintija Ukše (siins)

By Sam Boyd (inverts)

By Federico Iglesias

By Amanda J. Ellis

By Sharkbomb

By Rebecca George


Commission Examples

All by Dani Romero (Dis)


Other Ways You Can Help

Link this campaign to your Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, anywhere you can! Buff ladies need some lovin' too, and you can help make this happen!


Thank you for checking this out!! :)

story:
Short Summary

I have been gifted with a ticket to burning man and wanting to make the most out of my VERY FIRST experience by bringing the Art of Drag to the burner nation. Seeing as that I'm in a job transition, I'm strapped for cash and I can't do this alone! 

I've heard so much about how transformational burning man is and being a transformational being myself I would love to experience it. But also bring the art of gender transformation to the camp.  

What We Need 

  • Funding for Camp Dues 
  • Essentials Budget to buy camping supplies 
  • Costume Budget to produce amazing costumes

The Impact

To bring more awareness to drag also known as the Art of Illusion and seeing as that Burning Man is the epitome of all forms of Art it is about time that this form of art to not fly under the radar another year! 

I will publishing a full editorial photo shoot with all the sickening outfits and walking around burning man melting my face off from being so hot!! :P But more importantly being able to experience this transformational event. 

    Risks & Challenges

    There is the huge risk of me not being able to go because of Camp Dues and being in a job transition I dont know exactly where my next paycheck is coming from. Short of working the corner of 18th and Castro. (JK)


    So my question to you is,,, 

    Can you help a queen out!?

story:
The Year of the Ram!

In Chinese astrology, it is believed that the Ram is the most artistic sign in the zodiac. To celebrate creative energy of this year's Zodiac Animal, we are bringing a FLUFFY GIANT YARN POM POM RAM to Chinatown... and WE NEED YOUR HELP!


I'm sorry... a GIANT WHAT?!

GIANT. YARN. POM POM RAM. -  Ovies aries is known for their fleecy cuddly coats. We want to recreate the star of the year in giant proportions. We have a 4ft. frame ready, and throughout the celebratory festival (mark your calendars, Feb. 21st!) we will be crafting yarn pom poms to completely outfit our Ram in a new downy coat of... POM POMS!


What We Need

We need YARN. Lots of YARN. - our Ram will be covered in thousands of yarn pom poms, help us get the raw materials - framing and yarn - by making a small contribution to our campaign!

and HANDS. lots of HANDS.  - another way to pitch-in? Put yourself to work and join us Saturday February 21st in Chinatown to help us make, and attach, pom poms!


Community Art

This project is meant to bring all of Los Angeles, no matter your background, your age, or... your favorite color! to come together and celebrate the Chinese New Year, and this year's star... the RAM!


Don't forget to help us by SHARING WITH YOUR FRIENDS!

story:
El libro está disponible en www.elsewhere.es

The book is available on www.elsewhere.es

WHAT?

/ ELSEWHERE is a book with a compilation from ESCIF last 5 years. Not just about murals, but also with sketches, drawings, ideas, feelings, recipes, deep secrets and everyday life thoughts. This is not a book about ESCIF work. This is a work about ESCIF book

/ We printed a first edition of 1000 copies. Hard cover, 330 PAGES, sized 17,5 x 24 cm, full color in 4 different papers and different tastes...

///

/ELSEWHERE es un libro con una recopilación de los últimos 5 años de ESCIF. No solo de murales, pero tambien con bocetos, dibujos, ideas, sentimientos, recetas, secretos profundos y pequeñas anecdotas . No es un libro sobre el trabajo de ESCIF. Es un trabajo sobre el libro de ESCIF.

/ Hemos impreso una primera edición de 1000 copias. Tapa dura, 330 PAGINAS a todo color, tamaño  17,5 x 24 cm, en 4 papeles diferentes  y diferentes texturas....




/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

Imagenes de ESCIF

Texto de SANTIAGO ALBA RICO

Diseño de ENRIQUE CASP / romboide.net


/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////


If you like the project but you can´t support it economically, you can support it by:

SPREAD THE WORD!


Share a link to our project on your blog, website or whatever you can think of!

story:
Send Con Artist to Art Basel Miami 2013!

Art Basel is the leading contemporary art fair in the world. With 150 members, Con Artist is one of the largest and most active artist collectives in New York City. Our mission is to exhibit at Art Basel for the first time this year, and we need your help to do it.

Con Artist is a collective workspace and gallery in the Lower East Side of NYC, a gritty neighborhood with a notoriously punk rock history. We’ve been growing for the past four years, hosting new exhibitions every three weeks and partnering with other organizations like CultureFIX, Chashama and Recession Art. Recently the space doubled: we added a street-level gallery and storefront upstairs from our underground studio.

It’s easy to get lost on the contemporary art scene, especially in NYC. But Con Artist Collective represents an incredibly important demographic, eager and emerging artists. We refuse to be lost. We are the ones working all day and through the night , fighting for the space and attention our work deserves. So we couldn’t help but build a support system, a creative infrastructure.

All donations will help us break even on expenses (shown below), and will be reciprocated with acknowledgement, gifts, and a lasting relationship with a remarkable network. If you’re part of a company or organization, we’d love to discuss a customized promotional exchange.

Exactly how much will it cost to exhibit at Art Basel?

$1200/per person (does not include materials)

The below budget is broken down for 15 people, for campaign & travel expenses only:

Booth: $5,000

3 bedroom rental house @ 1 week: $2500

Transportation on-site (1 car rental, 10 bike rentals): $1,000

Food (Cooking/preparing own food) : $5,250

Flights: $4500 (15 @ $300)


Sub Total: $18,350

10% fees: $1835

Gift production/material costs: $2,000


Total: $22,185


Our Artists:

www.sarahwangart.com

www.heikebuelau.com

http://angelaviens.com

http://www.peterwyip.com

http://sessalund.prosite.com

http://jasminezimmerman.us

http://www.charlottesegall.com

http://sonjalessley.com

http://www.elkerevasudin.com

http://yeahimaudrey.tumblr.com

http://www.pauljohninternetart.info

https://www.facebook.com/john.arzayus1

http://www.rachelromanowsky.com

patrickgrz.tumblr.com

Www.miriambraverman.com

http://bhekisherman.com

www.travisfrick.com

Other Ways You Can Help

Any one of you who is just not in the position to give money would be of huge help to us by simply sending this campaign on to their network, talking about us and telling about our adventure to Art Miami Basel. Every single person added to our pool of people who know is a gift you give to us.

And don't forget to use the INDIEGOGO SHARE TOOLS...

THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU!!!

story:
Who We Are

For nearly 15 years, Jess Curtis/Gravity has been captivating audiences the world over with body-based performance art using a variety of disciplines including contemporary dance, physical theater, live music, and aerial acrobatics. Founder and Artistic Director, Jess Curtis, has created a body of work ranging from the underground extremes of Mission District Warehouses with Contraband and CORE (1985-1998) to the formal refinement and exuberance of European State Theaters and Circus Tents with Compagnie Cahin-Caha (1992-2002) and Jess Curtis/Gravity (2000-present).

Jess Curtis, Artistic Director, Gravity

Dually-based in San Francisco and Berlin, Jess Curtis/Gravity aspires to the creation of exceptionally engaging body-based art that explores and addresses issues and ideas of substance and relevance to a broad popular public.

What We Are Doing

We are raising funds for the US premiere of Performance Research Experiment #2.2 (PRE#2.2), January 30 - February 1, 2014 at the Joe Goode Annex in San Francisco, CA.

PRE#2.2 is the latest phase of our Performance Research Experiment, an ongoing performance project attempting to marry art and science - questioning and quantifying the physical effects of artistic performance on the body.

In an era where software updates to applications have become ubiquitous and necessary in order to pursue optimal operating efficiency and seamless user experience, we are rolling out a sinewy revamp of a piece that came to life this past spring in both SF and Berlin. Over the past several months, we have significantly reconfigured the work to provide a more seamless and theatrical user experience.

Jess, Jörg, and Yoann testing media integration in PRE#2.2 

PRE#2.2 features Gravity Artistic Director and Performer Jess Curtis, acclaimed Montpellier-based German circus artist Jörg Müller and Berlin-based French media artist Yoann Trellu in a rigorous yet personal body-based examination into the impact of performance—and the confounding paradoxes that only the human heart seems capable of producing.

Jess and Jörg testing effort empathy in PRE#2.2

Together, these artists will pull from the audience quantifiable data measuring the engagement and response of the spectator. Once collected this data streamed live, in real-time, throughout the performance. Thus without setting a foot onstage the audience itself, either by being measured or comparing themselves to those who are, become part of the machinery that moves the performance. Can science and data build a better artistic performance? With your help, we can find out.

What You Can Do

We need the support of our community to get our incomparable collaborators - Yoann and Jörg - to San Francisco for the US premiere of PRE#2.2. This will cost us exactly $4,260 dollars, and pay for air and ground travel, accommodations and per diem for their stay in SF.

   

Yoann Trellu & Jörg Müller

Our total budget for the project is $40,330. We have most other things covered - artist fees, venue, production supplies, publicity - thanks to support from the NEA Art Works, the Kenneth Rainin Foundation, the Zellerbach Family Foundation, the San Francisco Art Commission, San Francisco Grants for the Arts, among others. We need your help to close the gap.

Be it a lot or a little, we ask you to give us some money so that we may bring these internationally acclaimed artists together in San Francisco to put on a show for you. It’s as simple as that.

Jess and Jörg sing the Simple Song and test amplified vibration in PRE#2.2

Of course, there’s something in it for you. Perks. You can read all about them to the right. We’re also a non-profit, so your gift is tax-deductible too!

Why It Matters

While measurement of the autonomic nervous system – heart rate, respiration, blood pressure, etc., etc., have been used in the past to test movie and television audience response in research settings, the use of it as part of a performance, one that allows the part of the audience not being measured to compare themselves to that segment which is, is a much less predictable and less well-tread phenomenon.

“Trying to make ‘art’ out of data may seem a little antithetical,” says Curtis, but our success touring Performance Research Experiment #1 over the last several years, made us believe in the friction between the intuitive and the analytical.  This most recent ‘software update’ removes some dramaturgical glitches, has stylish new updated graphics and sound, and runs much faster for a generally greatly enhanced user experience.”

Jess and Jörg perform Performance Research Experiment #1. Photo by Sven Hagolani

Want to do more?

Visit us at our website, like us on Facebook, or join our mailing list to stay current on all things PRE#2.2 and Jess Curtis/Gravity.

the Arts, among others. We need your help to close the gap.
Be it a lot or a little, we ask you to give us some money so
that we may bring these internationally acclaimed artists together in San
Francisco to put on a show for you. It’s as simple as that.
Jess and Jörg sing the Simple Song and test amplified vibration in PRE#2.2Of course, there’s something in it for you. Perks. You can
read all about them to the right. We’re also a non-profit, so your gift is
tax-deductible too!
Why It Matters
While measurement of the autonomic nervous system – heart
rate, respiration, blood pressure, etc., etc., have been used in the past to
test movie and television audience response in research settings, the use of it
as part of a performance, one that allows the part of the audience not being
measured to compare themselves to that segment which is, is a much less
predictable and less well-tread phenomenon.
“Trying to make ‘art’ out
of data may seem a little antithetical,” says Curtis, but our
success touring Performance Research Experiment #1 over the last several years,
made us believe in the friction between the intuitive and the analytical.
 This most recent ‘software update’ removes some dramaturgical glitches,
has stylish new updated graphics and sound, and runs much faster for a generally
greatly enhanced user experience.”
Jess and Jörg perform Performance Research Experiment #1. Photo by Sven HagolaniWant to do more?Visit us at our website, like us on Facebook, or join our mailing list to stay current on all things PRE#2.2 and Jess Curtis/Gravity.

story:
Short Summary

"A man and a woman. They always sit on these two bar stools, looking out the window. They don't look at each other very often or speak too loudly as if they are having a covert conversation. Each scene is a new day but it is always the same two people on the same two stools in the same coffee shop.                Which is the reason why they come."

This project is actually my senior thesis project for my final year at Cornish College of the Arts. I am a young theatre maker and I get this opportunity to make whatever kind of art I want to as both my debut into the Seattle arts community and also as an accumulation of all I've learned. I have written the play and now I am directing it as well.

I get no budget from my school to put on this project which is okay because I don't think it will cost much to actually do but what I'm asking for funding for is compensation for the other artists who are helping me to make this, sort of dream project, come true for me.

What We Need & What You Get

A large majority of the money will go to compensation of the other artists involved. I especially want to pay Mitchell Gustin who is composing a 40ish minute score to go under the entire performance and who is paying live musicians out of his own pocket.

I would also compensate Ryan McAtee who is choreographing 10-12 short movement pieces that serve as transitions between the scenes and, of course, my wonderful actors Taylor Westerlund and Marissa Castillo for giving up their summer to help me make my dreams come true.

The last (but nowhere near least) party that I would like to compensate is Wheelhouse Coffee who has, generously, donated their space not only for our three performances but also as rehearsal space every weekend for 4 months. They aren't asking us to pay a cent. They are just happy to support young artists but I would love to be able to pay them for their kindness.

The grand total of the amount of compensation I'm hoping for is around $300. The rest of the funding would go towards advertising to get as many people in that coffee shop as we can to see the fruition of all this hard work.  A small amount would be used for costumes and props so neither the actors nor myself need to dip into our own pockets.

If we don't receive the full asking goal, I will split what we do raise and use it fully as compensation and cover the rest on my own.

The Impact

Your contribution would mean so much to both me and my collaborators who are, selflessly, working so hard to help me accomplish my senior thesis project. For me to be able to thank them monetarily (especially since they have all signed on to do it for free), would really be a help in my attempt to express a gratitude that is immeasurable. 

I thank you so much for your consideration and contribution.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! 

We will have three performances : September 19th, 20th, and 21st at 8pm at Wheelhouse Coffee (2113 Westlake Ave, Seattle, WA 98121). An audience is the best reward for the performers and musicians that are putting themselves out there as well as the choreographer and composer (and the director) who have their vision play out in front of them. Admission is free so please come or tell people who might be interested!

Please support Wheelhouse Coffee if you're ever in the South Lake Union area (or Lighthouse Coffee if you are ever in Fremont). I am not the only young artist that they have helped support and that kind of generosity is so important to cultivating a creative world.
