story:
SKIN: A MEDITATION a multi-media installation created by Valerie Barnes and Julia Knight.


FROM VALERIE AND JULIA, CO-CREATORS OF SKIN.

Welcome to “SKIN: A Meditation”. Our project began a few years ago when I voiced to Julia my interest in creating a visual interpretation of one of her poems. I had just finished working on another visual arts film and was inspired to begin another collaboration.
Not long after mentioning my idea, Julia handed me a poem she had written when traveling to the midwest. The poem was titled “SKIN” and it’s subject matter was the story of her living with Melanoma and recalling the experience of healing after her first surgery. I realized that this poem’s subject would make a compelling and thought-provoking film.

Little did we know the journey we were about to embark on.

SKIN, has now become a project that is gaining momentum and generating excitement. Timothy Cramer, Kimia Rahgozar and Jose Vargas have jumped on board to work with us because they share our belief that SKIN can have a powerful impact on all those that experience it.

Larendee Roos, owner of Roos Consulting, has also joined our team and brought her business expertise in helping us strategize the project.

We have also created a Board of Directors for SKIN which now has 3 members.

WHAT IS SKIN: A Meditation

SKIN is a multi-media installation combining film, poetry, photography, surround sound and interactive elements which invite the viewer to immerse themselves into an environmental meditation.

We want to blur the line that creates division between people based on age, race, and gender as we seek to continue a dialogue about self-respect and perception.

NUTS AND BOLTS

The centerpiece of the installation is a film diptych of Julia Knight’s poetry supported by Timothy Cramer's sound design. A gallery of photographs (some of which are included in the film) by Kimia Rahgozar, will be shown in a separate room.

SKIN will be also be experienced through interactive elements:

Video selfies will be displayed on monitors in the space. We are using social media as a tool to ask individuals to send in a 10 second soundbite expressing how they feel about their skin. Twenty (20) submissions will be selected for inclusion in our installation.

Writing boards will be hung in the space prompting people to express “How they live in their skin.”

WHAT WE NEED

Our goal is to raise $25,000. This seed money will be put towards securing a NYC gallery, completing the surround sound design and executing a digital media strategy.

OUR MISSION — “THE NEW NORMAL”

See and appreciate those around you
Kindness and respect towards others
Inside and out, we love all SKIN
Necessary care: protect your skin with annual dermatology visits, applying sunscreen, wearing protective clothing and saying goodbye to tanning beds.

WE INVITE YOU TO CONTRIBUTE IF:


• you have skin
• you or someone you love has been diagnosed with Melanoma
• you or someone you love has been diagnosed with other skin related health issues
• you have faced challenges in living in your SKIN and want to enter this haven of  
   SKIN appreciation
• you believe this project will help in raising awareness of the beauty and   
   importance of SKIN
• you believe that this project will encourage others to respect SKIN
• you have been the victim of hateful speech because of your SKIN
• you want to pursue a journey of compassion & self-reflection that gifts   
   understanding and forgiveness for the past
• you want to lend your voice in celebrating SKIN in all its diversity


WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS WILL HELP US DO LONG-TERM

We envision our project being shown on a local, national and global scale in galleries, museums and/or public art spaces. People of all ages, races and genders will be able to experience SKIN. Being attached to this project means you are participating in an installation that will make a positive global impact on how individuals feel about their skin and the skin of others.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

• Spread the word by sharing our project on social media sites such as Facebook ,Instagram, Pinterest, and Twitter #GRINFORSKIN

• Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools.


FINAL THOUGHTS
We are blessed to live in our skin. It’s existence is immeasurable. It’s fragility is a reminder of our mortality. It’s presence is fleeting. We choose to honor it for it’s beauty and importance.

FIND THIS CAMPAIGN ON:
Facebook: (eyelovemyskin)
Pinterest: (eyelovemyskin)
Twitter:     @eyelovemyskin #GRINFORSKIN
Website:   eyelovemyskin.com

Valerie Barnes ~Cinematographer, Editor + Exec Producer/Co-Creator of SKIN Valerie’s work has appeared on A&E, HLNtv, Fox Entertainment, Discovery, PBS and MSNBC. Her films have also been included in museum and gallery exhibits such as The Chelsea Museum and The City Museum of New York. Most recently, her cinematography for Jil Guyon’s “Widow” has been selected for numerous film festivals including Lincoln Center’s Dance On Camera 2014 Festival and Tour. It has won awards for Best Experimental Film and Best Short Film from the La Jolla Indie Film Festival.


Julia Knight ~Writer, Actress + Executive Producer and Co-Creator of SKIN
Julia has performed in Regional Theatre and Off-Broadway and has done over 70 TV commercials. Her television work has included appearances on Law & Order SVU (NBC), The View (CBS), Body and Soul (PBS) and All My Children. Voice-over Campaigns for TV include: TJ Max, Toys R US, Radio Spots for Oasis Day Spa, Aveeno, Xerox, and Voice work for the National Museum of American History .  She served as a panelist on 2 seasons of "Coffee Shop Confessions" on the popular Cafe Mom social network site for mothers. She's currently filming “Her Tory” with director, Magaly Colimon. As part of a collaboration with Valerie Barnes and Kimia Rahgozar, Julia also performed, wrote poetry and text for "Passerby", a multi-media exhibit held  at The Etemad Gallery in Tehran. She holds a BFA in Drama from University of North Carolina School of the Arts.

Timothy Cramer ~Sound Designer + Contributing Artist to SKIN
Tim has been involved in the architectural as well as exhibit design fields where he has created interactive music and education exhibits for several Northeast museums and historical institutions. Recently completed projects include an extensive interactive audio & video installation for the Children's Museum of Manhattan's "Eat Sleep, Play"; sound design for "After 911"; and for tv commercials including Dell Computers, Coca-Cola, Dentyne Ice and Bacardi Rum.

Kimia Rahgozar ~ Photographer + Contributing Artist to SKIN
Kimia's work has been shown in numerous galleries across the world including Canada, Dubai, England, Iran and Turkey. Her solo exhibitions include: Photosophy, a performance in Etemad Gallery (Tehran), You (Mekic Art Gallery - Montreal), Group Exhibits include: Iran Contemporary (1x1 Gallery, Dubai); She has also been invited to lecture and present Photosophy at Boston College (2013) and NYCAMS (2011). Most recently, she collaborated with Valerie Barnes and Julia Knight on "Passerby", a multi-media exhibit recently held in Etemad Gallery, Tehran. Kimia holds a BSc degree in Electronic Engineering from Azad University, Tehran, and is a member of IRAN.AIPA and CAPA (Canadian Art Photographers Association).

Jose Vargas ~ Installation Designer for SKIN
Jose's vast knowledge of the art world has stemmed from relationships formed through working as a Designer and Account Executive at Duggal Visual Solutions where he has helped in the production and design of installations for artists such as Andres Serrano, Cindy Sherman and Joseph Kosuth. He has acted as an artist's liaison with institutions including MoMA, The Metropolitan Museum, The Rubin Museum and The Mingei Museum in San Diego. Originally from the Dominican Republic, he studied Architecture, Design and Fine Art Photography at CUNY University in New York City.

Larendee Roos ~Executive Business Advisor + Executive Producer for SKIN
Larendee Roos is the founder of Roos Consulting. She has over 25 years of experience working with leaders to authentically lead and develop teams that maximize core performance. She is the Corporate and Executive Fixer. Larendee has dedicated her career to helping her clients figure out what they want and focus on achieving it through her own results-driven 6 Step Core Development System designed to serve short and long term goals. Larendee is known for her unique ability to see the big picture and find practical, useful solutions for the challenges executives face today. Throughout Larendee's career, she has provided business strategy and operations management for over 200 top management teams inside of small, medium and large organizations. Former business associates have called Larendee their trusted “secretary of state” with an eagle’s eye for focus. She has the ability to consult with executives and within the first session identify the primary obstacles that are standing in the way of goal achievement. Every client leaves their first session having identified their challenges equipped with a program that provides solid, actionable goals that will ensure success in their business, relationships and life. She has a Liberal Arts Education in Psychology from the University of Phoenix, Evangel University, and the University of Utah.


Alan Cohen ~ Executive Business Advisor + Executive Producer for SKIN   

Alan Cohen provides business advisory services to small businesses and entrepreneurs around the world.  Prior to starting his own coaching and strategic consulting business, Alan served as the Director of Communications for The Broadway League, the national trade association for the commercial theatre industry, presenter of the Tony Awards. 

He also served as Director of Corporate Training and Development for Scholastic,

where he established and supervised the company’s management training curriculum.

At Scholastic, he was also Director of Publicity and led the publicity team promoting

the acclaimed Harry Potter book series.  Alan holds a bachelor’s degree in English and Theatre from Connecticut College, and an MBA from Fordham University’s Graduate School of Business, where his focus was leadership development.  

He is an accredited member of the International Coach Federation (ICF) and is one of only 2,000 Professional Certified Coaches in the world.

story:
As we enter our seventh year of operation, we reach out to you at a time of critical growth for Co-Lab Projects.  While arts organizations come and go in our cultural community, we are continuing to further secure our place as a long lasting and sustainable venture. We decided to seek a new long-term rental space for our east side location that will better suit our needs as a rapidly growing organization.

Recently, we have secured a space that will enable us to more freely execute our programs, maintain open hours, post signage and increase the overall breadth of our programming and artist services. In this new location, we will be providing affordable studio space to artists, fabrication shop, offices, common spaces and a larger, more suitable gallery for our developing exhibitions and programming. This new business model will allow us to direct all of our income from donors and grants into development and programming, thereby increasing the level and scope of our production.

The new facilities will be ready in the early months of 2015. We will be finishing the 2014 program at 613 Allen and start our 2015 programming at the new space. As a member of our cultural community and audience, we are requesting your support in this time of expansion in whatever way you are able. We are attempting to raise $20,000 to assist in permitting, build out, and beautification of the new venue as well as the launch of our 2015 programming.

In addition to your donation being fully tax deductible (via FirstGiving), and as a show of appreciation for your contribution, we are offering tailored packages of gift cards, merchandise, meals, and products. Check them out in the perks section of our campaign! Pictures of some items may be found under the Gallery tab above.

With your support, Co-Lab Projects will continue to support risk and dialogue, expand artist resources, facilitate dynamic relationships between artists and audiences, and enhance the cultural landscape of Austin and Central Texas.

story:
PrairieSeen was founded by Tori McNish and Chelsey Van Weerden in the Fall of 2012 as an Edmonton-specific visual arts blog that brings viability and a new perspective to the visual arts community in our city. After two years of consistently creating content, we're taking it to the next level by launching an online magazine called PrairieSeen Notes that also covers the Edmonton visual arts exclusively. We are raising funds to support the launch of our first issue, to be released in September 2014.

Since we're a registered not-for-profit organization, all funds raised will go toward contributors honourariums (writers, designers, and visual artists) to compensate for quality work. We are paying 6-8 writers, 1 visual artist, and 1 graphic designer for their mad skills. A portion of the funds raised will also go toward spreading the word offline!

It's important to us to make this magazine as accessible as possible, which is why all issues will be completely and open-access - for everyone. It will exist online only to keep costs down. We want this project to become self-sustaining in the future, so any reserve funds will be carried forward for future issues. 

PrairieSeen has experiences increasing readership since its launch, with 13 000 page views in the last year alone. We expect readership to grow with our new publication format. We'll achieve this by continuing to produce quality, thoughtful, and accessible content. In the last year, we've produced over 20 artist feature interviews, dozens of weekly media round-ups, hosted regular guest writers, written multiple exhibition reviews, and highlighted countless local projects and events. Offline we've curated two exhibitions, hosted workshops and speaking events, and helped promote other arts initiatives in the city.

If you can't contribute financially, we'd be just tickled if you helped spread the word by sharing this page on social media and by old-fashioned word of mouth!
story_txt:
PrairieSeen was founded by Tori McNish and Chelsey Van Weerden in the Fall of 2012 as an Edmonton-specific visual arts blog that brings viability and a new perspective to the visual arts community in our city. After two years of consistently creating content, we're taking it to the next level by launching an online magazine called PrairieSeen Notes that also covers the Edmonton visual arts exclusively. We are raising funds to support the launch of our first issue, to be released in September 2014.
Since we're a registered not-for-profit organization, all funds raised will go toward contributors honourariums (writers, designers, and visual artists) to compensate for quality work. We are paying 6-8 writers, 1 visual artist, and 1 graphic designer for their mad skills. A portion of the funds raised will also go toward spreading the word offline!
It's important to us to make this magazine as accessible as possible, which is why all issues will be completely and open-access - for everyone. It will exist online only to keep costs down. We want this project to become self-sustaining in the future, so any reserve funds will be carried forward for future issues. 
PrairieSeen has experiences increasing readership since its launch, with 13 000 page views in the last year alone. We expect readership to grow with our new publication format. We'll achieve this by continuing to produce quality, thoughtful, and accessible content. In the last year, we've produced over 20 artist feature interviews, dozens of weekly media round-ups, hosted regular guest writers, written multiple exhibition reviews, and highlighted countless local projects and events. Offline we've curated two exhibitions, hosted workshops and speaking events, and helped promote other arts initiatives in the city.
If you can't contribute financially, we'd be just tickled if you helped spread the word by sharing this page on social media and by old-fashioned word of mouth!

story:
Tohoku Artist Caravan 2013

An Art and Music Project to Benefit Northeastern Japan produced by TokyoDex

 

An Art Project to Revitalize the Community

On 3/11/2011, the Tohoku region of Japan was changed forever by a colossal earthquake, tsunami, and the nuclear disaster that ensued. Nearly two years later, the region remains in shock and in need of support. While volunteers from all over Japan remain in the area to help survivors, the need for physical labor has dwindled and volunteers are looking to find new ways to best support local communities. The physical cleanup process is nearly complete, but life is by no means back to normal and spirits remain low. What is needed now is community outreach designed to energize people and celebrate life, rather than focusing on the disaster. The Tohoku Artist Caravan project produced by TokyoDex is exactly that.

The Artist Caravan will bring artists and musicians from all over Japan, and all over the world, to gather in the town of Karakuwa, Kesennuma to bring a much-needed cultural infusion to the area. This will be the beginning of a long-term art project designed to get locals involved and to bring visitors from across Japan, raising awareness and building the local economy. The initial art installations will be completed over a three-day period, culminating in an opening party that features many renowned musicians across multiple genres. This entire process will be filmed and include first-hand accounts from locals as well as participating artists to document the experience and help raise awareness of the current situation of a largely forgotten region that has fallen out of the news cycle.

Artist Caravan Members live painting at our annual "New Year Jam"

 

Karakuwa Artscape

One of the most striking comments we heard when visiting Karakuwa was about the “impenetrable gray” that has pervaded the landscape since the disaster. When the tsunami swallowed up whole districts of Karakuwa, it washed much of the town’s color out to sea, and even with the rubble removed and the town slowly recovering, the landscape remains bleak. The main initiative of the Tohoku Artist Caravan will be the “Karakuwa ArtScape,” an ongoing art initiative that will add color to the community and change the landscape in a powerful way. The artists we bring to Karakuwa will create several murals at various high-visibility areas that are also symbolic within the community. These large-scale works of art will not only serve as a memorial to the disaster, but also become beacons of hope for the future, beginning a permanent outdoor art exhibition that would be a powerful draw for tourism. Karakuwa ArtScape could be added to and updated on a periodic basis to really put the town of Karakuwa on the map as a cultural center. It would bring outside visitors, and their financial support, to the area for years to come.

Why Karakuwa

Karakuwa is a small town that is located on the eastern side of Kesennuma in the Prefecture of Miyagi that suffered a great deal of damage as a result of the 2011 Great Eastern Earthquake Tsunami. However, because of Karakuwa's relative small size and geographically isolated location on a small peninsula, it was largely overlooked immediately after the disaster. The very first responders for Karakuwa were actually US Navy. Karakuwa was fortunate to have many volunteers to assist in recovery and relief efforts, but the numbers didn't compare to many of the bigger cities across Tohoku. 

The Shibitachi area of Karakuwa, Kesennuma City, Miyagi in July 2011

"Broken Stone" landmark in Chouhanzou, Karakuwa. A Tsunami during the Meiji Period (circa 1868 to 1912) broke the stone

Karakuwa Scenery

Relief Volunteers in Karakuwa

 

Karakuwa ArtScape: Initial Sites

We have already received permission to create murals on two properties in Karakuwa

1. Oyster Processing Facility in Shibitachi

Shibitachi is a coastal area in Karakuwa known for its fishing industry. “Moriya-suisan,” an Oyster business run by local resident Ichiyo Kanno, was completely destroyed in the tsunami and rebuilt last year. The land that the facility stands on today is where some of her employees use to live. Their houses were destroyed and many lives were lost. Working extremely hard to rebuild her business, this year Ichiyo-san is finally able to process oysters again. But Shibitachi is still completely grey, and the once-lively town remains devastated. Bringing in artists to add some color to her newly reopened business will provide some much-needed color as well as hope for the future.

 

2. “Kaeru-Juku”

On 3/11, Kuniaki Baba lost his home which he built out of wood that was passed down from his mother, including pillars several hundred years old. He now lives in a small hut next to the lot where his home used to stand and has always opened his doors to house relief volunteers. The hut has been nicknamed “Kaeru-Juku,” (“Return House”), reflecting Baba-san’s open-door policy for all past volunteers who might wish to return to Karakuwa.

 

Energizing Local Youth and Planning for the Future

One of the most positive stories to emerge from the devastation that took place in 2011 was the powerful volunteer movement that emerged in the wake of the disaster.Thousands of young people quit whatever they were doing at the time to dive into the Tohoku area and make themselves useful in anyway possible-- removing rubble, cooking food, and providing care however they could. In 2013, the heavy lifting is over, but many of these young people have remained in local communities where they continue to be catalysts of change.This phenomenon was palpable in Karakuwa, where many residents described how this infusion of young people from outside their community had reenergized the town. They explained how they provided not only much-needed extra hands in the clean-up process, but also acted as role models that gave hope and purpose to local youth who were feeling defeated and at a loss as to how to move forward.

The “Karakuwa Rookies” is an initiative started by those volunteers who have remained in Karakuwa.They understand that the young people of the community are key to revitalization, and they have become the “glue” that bonds the local youth of Karakuwa together. One of their main goals in to get young locals to be become more involved in the community, to participate in local festivals and other gatherings, and to proactively plan for the future.The Kawakuwa Rookies have pledged their support to the Artist Caravan project, and in return, we will pledge a percentage of all funds raised to this group so that they may continue to do their good work and invest in the future of Karakuwa long after the Artist Caravan leaves town.

 

Opening Party: “Reunion”

When discussing various benefit events that had already taken place in the area, we learned that one of the most memorable ones was a visit from the internationally renowned taiko ensemble, Kodo. As fate would have it, Artist Caravan core team member D.H. Rosen has a long history with the Kodo drummers and a close personal relationship with members past and present, including a former member who was born and raised in Kesennuma. Assembling a group of former Kodo members to play together is something that has never been done before and would make for an incredible gathering of musicians who have already proved popular with the Karakuwa community. The opening party for this exhibition will take place in Kesenuma proper (venue to be determined) and will act as a celebratory kick-off and a vehicle to garner traffic to Karakuwa ArtScape.

(Participation by former Kodo members Ryutaro Kaneko,Tetsuro Naito, Kaoru Watanabe,Takahito Nishino, Tsubasa Hori, Natsuki Saito, confirmed as of 2/24/2013.)

 

The Website

The Artist Caravan website will be a “home base” for the project, designed to give general information about the project, and also to track the progress of the caravan in real time once the journey begins. This frequently updated website will include “check-ins” and photos of the journey along the way, as well as featuring an interactive map that indicates where the caravan is at any given time. Facebook and Twitter feeds embedded in the site itself will allow viewers to interact online with Caravan travelers and be a part of the experience.

 

A Multitalented Team

Artist/Producer: Jay Horinouchi

Artist Caravan core member and producer Jay Horinouchi has a strong connection with the community of Karakuwa. He acted as a volunteer and university student volunteer coordinator in Karakuwa for over a year, and has spent a lot of time developing close relationships with the people of the region. As an artist, Jay has been longing to host an energetic and colorful art event in Karakuwa for some time, but obviously the cleanup effort and other relief efforts held precedence. Now as the people of Tohoku are facing the second anniversary of the disaster, just as it is fading from public memory around the world, now is the perfect time to introduce the Tohoku Artist Caravan. 

Director: D.H. Rosen

Founder and creative director of TokyoDex, D.H. Rosen is a Tokyo-based artist/producer who has spent the past two decades in Japan working as a writer, visual artist, curator and creative director of events, films and multimedia projects.

Music Director: Kaoru Watanabe

Kaoru Watanabe is a former member of the Japanese taiko ensemble Kodo, and is a practitioner of various Japanese transverse bamboo flutes, the taiko drum, as well as Western flute. Kaoru toured across the globe with Kodo, performing the taiko, traditional Japanese folk dance and song, and especially the various fue (bamboo flutes). From 2005 to 2007, Kaoru served as one of Kodo’s artistic directors, focusing on their world music festival Earth Celebration. In late 2006 Kaoru left Kodo and returned to NY to teach and continue performing fue, western flute and taiko in a variety of musical and artistic settings.  

 

Perks

In addition to our heartfelt thanks, we ware also offering some original artist goodies! *Images below are just samples

Digital photo book documenting the whole trip through Northeastern Japan, including stories and interviews.

Zine, postcard sets, and stickers! Everything will be designed by participating artists!
Original member T-shirts. Be a "Team Member"!
 

Project Schedule

April 24, 2013: Caravan Launch!
April 25~27: Mural Painting On Site
April 28: Opening Party!
 
 
*Note from the Organizers
Thanks to everyone who has taken the time to read this far! We are super excited to make this happen and need your help! We have set our initial goal on Indiegogo at $10,000, but the more money we raise, the more artists we can get involved and the more amazing thiis project will become. We thank you in advance for your support!
 

About TokyoDex


TokyoDex is an artist collective equipped to assemble a customized consortium of talent for any creative project. The name “Dex” is derived from the word dexterous, which means ingenious,  clever, or skilled with one’s hands, a concept that aptly describes our wide range of capabilities.

http://www.tokyodex.com

Recent Client Work: "Redbull Curates Canvas Cooler Project" 2012

story:
Hello,

My name is David Lyle and I'm a full time artist residing in New York City. You can see my paintings at  www.davidlylepaintings.com.

I'm currently working on my first European solo show with Addict Galerie  www.addictgalerie.com in Paris, France occurring this September 12, 2013. Although I'm very excited to exhibit in France, I'm not so thrilled about the exuberant expense of shipping.  So this is where funding from all of you folks will help transport my work to Paris, accordingly. Due to the fact I paint on wood panels, I need to ship 15-20 large paintings in two large crates via international shipping.

What I Need & What You Get:

  -   $1,000.00  will go to packing materials and cost of building two large crates to ship my paintings. 

   -  $3,000.00- 4,000.00 will go to cost of shipping from New York to Paris, France and to cover taxes, Indiegogo, and PayPal costs.

Whoever contributes, will not only help me transport my work to France, but will also receive one of the following perks: Handmade postcards mailed from Paris; T-shirts from my painting "This Ends Here"; Prints from my Graffiti series; or even a commissioned painting. 

                                 Thanks,

                                        David

Whatever amount of contributions is realized will allow me to continue painting for upcoming shows here in NYC and ensure all of my work arrives in Paris timely and undamaged. 

 

 Other Ways You Can Help:

I know times are tough out there, so if you cannot help by donating, please help by spreading the word of my funding campaign!

story:
AZUSA CREATES the city's first annual arts festival

Our Story

Azusa Renaissance Theater has been around for over 10 years.  Founded in 2001 by Monica Ganas and Erin & Dave Gaw, the programs has become an integral role in parts of the Azusa community through expansion in arts education and theatrical exposure.


In November of 2010, the program officially merged with the Nonprofit CEDAR (Center for Education, Diversity, and Reconciliation) and is currently seeking funding to run and establish Azusa's first citywide arts festival.


The Impact

AZUSA CREATES is planned to run 3 days and will include performances in music, poetry, theater, & dance, visual art galleries, discussion forums, and artistic celebrations.  The goal of the festival is to provide a safe & open space for brand new and experienced artists to share their work in a the place they call "home".  It is our hopes that the art presented at the festival will encourage civic dialogue around the arts and its potential effects on community, education, and politics.  Azusa is a city of many cultures and generations, and it is our hope that the festival will reflect that.


This has the potential to become an annual event in the city, and your donation will be the building blocks for that potential.


What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to raise over $1500 to help cover the initial start-up costs of beginning such an endeavor.  We are open to any donations - large and small.  Anyone who donates (at any level) will be included in event literature as Founders of the Festival.  Breakdown of donation benefits below:


$1-$49

Receive your name in the Friends of the Festival section of event literature.


$50-$249

Receive your name in the Contributors of the Festival section of event literature.

Receive 2 complimentary tickets to attend the end of festival celebration.


$250 or more

Receive your name in the Cornerstones of the Festival section of event literature.

Receive 5 complimentary tickets to attend the end of festival celebration.

Receive website recognition as personal or business donor.


Other Ways You Can Help

By spreading the word about Azusa Renaissance and, more specifically, this fundraising campaign.  Azusa Renaissance Theater has and will always be a community effort.  So get the word out about what we are attempting to do, and help us reach our goal of $1500 or more by the end of November!

story:
I suffered a trauma-related brain injury (c-PTSD) and have been living with the support of the Ontario Disability Support Program. I am at the end of my trauma therapy at Women’s College Hospital, where i am enrolled in a visual art programme.

My work is shown at the SPEAKArt Gallery, Artscape Triangle Galleryt Roncy Rocks Festival, The Annex Patio Art show, Buddies In Bad Times, and at my official Scotiabank Nuit Blanche Installation in September. I want to use these opportunities to start a conversation about brain injury. Please help me get a refurbished Macbook Pro so I can continue to create art.

Please see my bio page for more info on who I am and what I do as well as links to my work, facebook, IMDb and blog.

I suffered a trauma-related brain injury (c-PTSD) and have been living with the support of the Ontario Disability Support Program. I am at the end of my trauma therapy at Women’s College Hospital, where i am enrolled in a visual art programme.
My work is shown at the SPEAKArt Gallery, Artscape Triangle Galleryt Roncy Rocks Festival, The Annex Patio Art show, Buddies In Bad Times, and at my official Scotiabank Nuit Blanche Installation in September. I want to use these opportunities to start a conversation about brain injury. Please help me get a refurbished Macbook Pro so I can continue to create art.
Please see my bio page for more info on who I am and what I do as well as links to my work, facebook, IMDb and blog.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Paul Lapusan, I am an artist that mainly works in pen and ink drawings. I received a degree in Studio Art from Saint Louis University and have been working as an artist and doing other small jobs since graduating. My work has been featured in many different venues and shows in the area including, Naughty Gras, Saint Louis Art Fair, Laumeir Art Fair, Koken Art Factory, and Mad Art Gallery. In addition to working on projects for these shows I make custom artwork and have been working on a few ideas for comic books. Progress on current works and projects can be seen on my facebook page.

The nitty gritty of this project is to be able to raise funds for a move into a new place where I will have more space to create. In addition funds will also go to a new scanner from which I will be able to archive my work better, and be able to print archival quality prints.

What We Need & What You Get

I have been drawing my whole life and being able to have time and space to do my art is something that is very special to me. While I have had successes with my art work so far, I am just starting my career as an artist. With more funding I can take more time to focus on my art which is the most important thing in my life.

For donating I will be giving out some of my own work both as prints and as originals. At higher levels there is even the option of custom work.  

Here are some examples of the type of work I do.

Impact

This campaign will affect my life by allowing me to continue to do what I love without as many stresses. With your help I can continue working on my current projects and not have to worry about taking long breaks in between my work to do other jobs. While I will continue to work and sell my artwork elsewhere I will be able to work a lot more on my long-term projects and finish them. I can also save my work in better quality and be able to provide more print options. Even if we do not reach goal the money raised will go to more supplies and time to do my work.

Other Ways You Can Help

My work is available on other sites including and Etsy Store, and a Society 6 Shop. If you do not feel inclined to donate here visiting and purchasing from those shops also helps. And please share this with anybody you can who is interested in the arts and helping an artist.

story:
With the ability to create your own character, the Dragon Age series offers players the chance to craft their own unique adventure. Many fans take that a step further, exploring their Wardens and Inquisitors through art, fanfic, comics, and more. This zine is a celebration of the passion and creativity that goes into these characters, with the artists and writers behind them creating their own tarot cards and codex entries like the ones found in the game. 

Art and codex by Kiku Hughes

Arcana: A Dragon Age Zine will be a 184 page, full color anthology, with 72 unique character illustrations and codex entries based on the 72 cards in both the Major and Minor Arcana suites. 

Art and codex by Anna Pan

 

We have fifty-four amazingly talented artists and writers who have contributed to the project, both collaborating and working independently. 

Aimo // Alex Lillie // Amanda Shae // Andrea Cely // Ann Chovi // Anna Pan //Annalise Jensen // Apollo // Caitlin Scannell // Destiny // Dianula // Elaine Tipping // Elemei // Eline // Emi // Eri Vermeersch // Erika Hollice // Fanny Rodriguez // Hannah "Bear/Burr" Herkert // Hannah Lawler // Hanna Schroy // Isabelle Chauvet // Ivan F. // Jackie Lee // Jasmine Young // Jenna // Jessica Taylor // Jojo // Jolyn Sandford // Kai M. Archuleta // Kay Fine // Kiku Hughes // Laskull // Laura Guglielmo // Laura R // Laura Taylor // Lauren Ashizawa // LaVonne Marshall // Ling // Limpstella // Mary Fountaine // Max Dlabick // Momo // Natalie Padberg Bartoo // Phineas Sargent // River-bird // Siona // Susana Gonzalez // Vir Ghilani // vlwv // Xfreischutz // Yotty Kim // Zackary Doy

 

 

We have several different reward tiers to make the project as accessible as possible to people, including both digital PDF and physical versions of the book. 

The book itself is an estimated 184 pages in length, with 72 full color illustrations of each of the cards in the Major and Minor Arcana as well as coinciding codex entries. It will be softbound, at 7.5" x 10" and with gold foil detailing on the cover. All book orders come with a digital DRM-free PDF of the book, which can also be ordered separately.

All qualifying tiers will receive a 3.75" x 5" sticker sheet designed by one of our contributors, Hanna Schroy! 

A set of four 5" x 7" full color mini prints done by four different artists in the zine, each based on one of the Minor Arcana suits as well as one of the races of Thedas. 

We have five artists offering commission tiers for the zine, which gets you the physical book, stickers, mini prints, as well as a single character full body, full color commission by your artist of choice (as long as they have slots available). Commissions will begin once the zine campaign wraps up, when we'll put you in touch with your artist so you can give them the details for your image. So if you'd like an amazing drawing of your Inquisitor or Hawke to go along with your zine, this is the tier for you!

The contributing artists for this tier are...

The main focus of our budget is to cover the printing expenses of the books (via PrintNinja), and meeting our donation goal of $3,750 to the ACLU. The printing costs for the books cover the cost of the minimum order of 500 books, though if we do manage to actually sell 500 copies of the zine we'll exceed our goal of $12,000 and be able to make a much larger donation to the ACLU. Barring that, any excess copies of the zine will be made available online, with all profits being donated to charity. 

 

 

Lauren Ashizawa and Caitlin Scannell are both comic artists who spend maybe a little too much time drawing fanart of their Lavellans and coming up with Dalish headcanons. When they’re not crying over elves, Caitlin runs a space age fantasy comic, Heir Presumptive, and Lauren runs a high fantasy comic called Innkeeps. They both self-publish their work and regularly exhibit at comic conventions across the US and Canada.

Risks & Challenges

The major risk we face in this campaign is not hitting our funding goal, and being unable to cover printing costs as well as not being able to donate our goal of $3,750 USD to the ACLU. Though this is a little larger scale than we're used to, being indie comic artists means both of the editors are familiar with book production and printing. The majority of artist cards and codex entries are already completed, and the rest should be completed before the campaign wraps up. There's always a chance for delays in production, including shipping delays and proof adjustments, and we intend to keep both backers and contributors updated in the event of any setbacks.

In the event that the campaign is not fully funded, we have chosen the flexible funding option to ensure both the backers and the contributors receive their copies of the books and other rewards. We will do a smaller run of the books with a company called RA Comics Direct, which both editors regularly use print our own comics, though this will make the cost per unit slightly higher and we won't be able to reach our initial donation goal of $3750 for the ACLU.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't afford to support the zine, you can help us reach our goal by sharing and promoting it on social media! You can find us on Tumblr at @da-arcana or on Twitter at @arcanaDAzine, and Indiegogo offers links to share the campaign directly on sites like Facebook and Twitter. 

We'd also like to remind you to follow and support the contributors of this zine on social media! 

 

This is a fan-run zine that is in no way affiliated with Bioware. Funds will be handled by Caitlin Scannell and Lauren Ashizawa. Project organizers will receive no monetary compensation from the campaign. Primary project coordinator is Caitlin Scannell, with co-organization by Lauren Ashizawa. Publishing and fulfillment by Caitlin Scannelll and Lauren Ashizawa.

We'd also like to remind you to follow and support the contributors of this zine on social media! 
 
This is a fan-run zine that is in no way affiliated with Bioware. Funds will be handled by Caitlin Scannell and Lauren Ashizawa. Project organizers will receive no monetary compensation from the campaign. Primary project coordinator is Caitlin Scannell, with co-organization by Lauren Ashizawa. Publishing and fulfillment by Caitlin Scannelll and Lauren Ashizawa.

story:
Why go to Vidcon 2017?

My name is Ian Garland and I am the Off Kilter Crafter on Youtube. I have been making Youtube videos for the past 3 years and have built my channel from the ground up. I have had great opportunities that have helped my channel grow to almost 5,000 subscribers. I chose the name Off Kilter Crafter because no matter how hard I try, my cards are never perfect. So instead, I embrace the imperfections and make each project my own. The reason I want to go Vidcon is it will expand my horizons and give me experience, knowledge, information, connections, and friends who will help my Youtube channel grow. I am currently a smaller channel, and hope to bring back to my channel all that I learn at Vidcon. I will also have the opportunity to attend panels, Q&As, and activities. All of which will build my skills and create better Youtube content. With the support I receive I can bring it back around to you in my videos. 

What I Need & What You Get In Return:

Here are the expenses I need help with:

  • Airfare
  • Hotel
  • Food/Snacks
  • Transportation To/From Airport
  • Disneyland day for creators

In return I have several perks for you:

  • $5: A thank you email from me for your support.
  • $25: Behind the scenes access to a secret Facebook group for Facebook Live events, access to raw YouTube footage from each day.*  
  • $40: Special Vidcon SVG file and post card from Vidcon.
  • $65: One of a kind Off Kilter Crafter Tote Bag.
  • $100: One of a kind Off Kilter Crafter T-shirt.
  • $250: I will make a 10 pack of one layer cards for you to use.

*Subject to Wi-Fi availability.

Any left over funds I will use those for  a contingency fund to have with me while at Vidcon. Once back home, I will use any left over money to help buy new video equipment for better camera shots, as well as crafting supplies and/or tools. Those products will then be helpful tools for my future videos.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that you may not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Let other people know about my campaign by using the Indiegogo share tools on this page.
  • If you go to crops or other crafty social events, ask your fellow crafters to support my campaign if they can, and tell them about my Youtube channel. 
  • Whatever you can do to let your friends, family, and coworkers know about my campaign.

story:
Dusty friends, family, and friends of family and family of friends!

Burning Man 2018 saw the culmination of hundreds of community work hours donated by dozens of individuals over three years resulting in a milestone year for the Pariah Express. 

The 10 days in the desert were filled with camaraderie between camp-mates and citizens of BRC who joined Pariah in reveling and celebrating this amazing festival day after night, after day …... she ran flawlessly throughout.

As we all know, the Playa provides but the road home can throw some obstacles in our direction.. Our journey back to Default-ia last year saw the unraveling  of a few mechanical components along our return route which are preventing us from being road strong to make it back to the playa for 2019. None are insurmountable nor technically complicated.

Pariah Express’s 2019 Day License invitation flew through DMV review without a hitch.  However her Night License invitation came with a Scarlet Letter “CONDITIONAL for NIGHT”.  Read: MORE LIGHTS or ELSE

The hour is late, and the Pariah would greatly appreciate your generosity in order to complete the final Lighting updates, mechanical repairs and maintenance and finishing the work that was started three years ago.   To be road ready and to get us to the entrance cue to Black Rock City and beyond. 

 In a time where deadlines are creeping up for everyone and the “plenty of time" lists  are turning to “last minute" lists, we humbly ask for your help in getting the Pariah Express delivered to Burning Man 2019 for the continued collaborative, and creative magic she has provided to hundreds and to get her into the permanent Playa-ready state she has already earned and deserves.   

Much love, Pariah  xxoo

story:
We are told that the country is divided. The divide I find most complex and interesting is the line we draw between local individual identity, and global identity. I am hard-pressed to find someone who feels rightfully represented by our mass media dialogue, yet, when it comes to understanding other groups and individuals, mainstream social and corporate media sources provide most of our knowledge. As individuals we are sorted, categorized and fictionalized by mainstream dialogues. Local identity is globalized through the exchange of digital media, and meanwhile these global narratives also materialize locally, in the forms of laws, mailboxes, protests, Home Depot gardens and Bikram Yoga studios. My project aims to explore the material interface that negotiates this encounter between global and local identity. I will do so, in part, by using objects to activate new channels of long distance, personal communication. The goal is to draw attention to the ways materials engage in their own political dialogues and express their own global concerns. I want to focus on communication that lives 'in the flesh' rather than in the cloud.  

The highway will be my avenue. I'll be driving south from the Bay Area and then heading east, spending time in settlements of every sort--cities, towns, parks, ghost towns, ruins and truck stops. My only plan is to meet people and carry out my directives. 

The directives are sponsored by Donors. When you donate you acknowledge your multiple personalities: subject, object and enzyme. You will choose a perk that directly influences the direction and content of my journey, and that also activates some aspect of your identity in an unplanned future location. Most of the perk options put you in direct social-material dialogue with a distant place. 

I believe a more humane world depends directly upon a more honest approach to the way we connect to and extend through the materials around us--food, roads, forests, trash, toys, coins, etc. Global warming, resource scarcity, extinction and oil wars all result from our unwillingness to reconsider our relationship with our physical environments. Our focus on humans as the only 'active,' 'thinking,' 'choice making,' and 'valuing' entities, limits an honest approach to the way objects and media act through and upon our choices and character. This is an ecological, political and philosophical endeavor to look for vitality in objects. While it will sound to many like indulgence in a fantasy, I agree with Timothy Morton when he writes, "the lineage that brought us slavery and racism is also the lineage that brought us the anthropocentric boundary between human and nonhuman." It may be very worth while to look beyond these boundaries.

story:
Objekt—a reading room

WHY NOT SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN ON YOUR SOCIAL MEDIA NETWORK?

Please help fund the Royal Canadian Academy of Arts' exhibition Objekt—a reading room * at SUPERMARKET 2021: Stockholm Independent Art Fair, Stockholm, Sweden, October 13–17, 2021. Objekt will be a reading room where art fair attendees can freely peruse bookworks by 32 contemporary Canadian artists. You donation will enable two artist-hosts, Josée Dubeau, RCA and Robert Tombs, RCA, to travel with the exhibition components, and to set up and present the exhibition over five days.

These bookworks contain text and image such as were determined by our selection of artists, designers, craftspersons, essayists and publishers. Confirmed participating artists are Diane Leclair Bisson, Deanna Bowen, Jane Buyers, Ginette Caron, Amanda Dawn Christie, Sorel Cohen, Christos Dikeakos, Josée Dubeau, Pnina C. Gagnon, Adrian Göllner, Jerry Grey, Wesley Harris, Lucy Hogg, Thaddeus Holownia, Geoffrey James, Peter Krausz, Guy Lavigueur, Naoko Matsubara, Gordon Monahan, Robert Murray, Marie-Jeanne Musiol, Leslie Reid, Marina Roy, John A. Schweitzer, Nick Shinn, Michael Snow, Alan Stein, Penelope Stewart, Robert Tombs, Henk van Assen, George Weber, Andrew Wright and Jinny Yu. Additionally, Robert Tombs will give a presentation on artist's books, and Objekt participant Gordon Monahan, a 2012 Governor General's Visiual And Media Arts laureate, will present the sound performance Boiling Water.

The city of Stockholm stands on fourteen islands on Sweden's south-central east coast. According to legend, the city's name tells you how it was born: as a fortress made of logs ('stock') on an island ('holm') guarding the entrance to Lake Mälaren. Stockholm has been Sweden's political, cultural and economic center since the 1200s. SUPERMARKET 2021 will be held at Stadsgårdsterminalen, a former cruise ship terminal in Stockholm harbour, from October 13 to 17, 2021. SUPERMARKET has been presented in Stockholm since 2007 by a small group of 'kulture vultures', most of whom are artists. It is an evolution of Minimarket, which was first held at Konstnärshuset in 2006. Over the years SUPERMARKET has grown into the biggest art fair in the Nordic countries featuring hundreds of artists from all over the world.

*'Objekt' is the Swedish spelling for 'object', and a curatorial conceit for the physical book as it occupies space in the world.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $2085 to complete our budget. A selection of books are proposed here, donated by the artists, as suitable additions to any library, each one a living document from Canada's contemporary art and design scene. Why not add a book from Objekt—a reading room to your library and help us get to Stockholm?

The Impact

Canada is a long way from the galleries, artist-run centres and performance venues of Europe, South America and Asia. By cost-effectively promoting 32 artists in one event, we are creating an extended conversation that will certainly advance the careers of a number of Canadian artists.

Who We Are

The Royal Canadian Academy of Arts (RCA), is one of Canada’s oldest continually-operating artist-run organizations. We receive no operational funds from the Canada Council, and depend almost exclusively on membership dues and occasional project grants, The RCA was founded in 1880 by Canada’s Governor General, John Campbell, 9th Duke of Argyll in conjunction with the establishment of the National Gallery of Canada.

Our earliest members include painter Lucius R. O’Brien, first President of the RCA, and architect/painter Napoléon Bourassa, first Vice-President. Distinguished Academicians have since included painters Marcel Barbeau, Ghitta Caiserman-Roth, Marcelle Ferron, Clarence Gagnon, Yves Gaucher, Betty Goodwin, Lawren P. Harris, Gershon Iskovitz, Garry Neill Kennedy, Daphne Odjig, Mary Pratt, Marc-Aurèle de Foy Suzor-Coté and Frederick Varley; filmmakers Paul Almond, Evelyn Lambart and Norman McLaren; architects Charles P. Baillargé, Guy Desbarats, Arthur Erickson and John C. Parkin; photographers Lynne Cohen, Samuel Tata and Yousuf Karsh; printmakers Kenojuak Ashevak and Pitseolak Ashoona; sculptor Kiugak Ashoona; silversmith Lois Etherington Betteridge; ceramicist Erica Deichman Gregg; and performance artist Colette Urban.

Today’s RCA is committed to assuring a diversity of members and artistic disciplines. Our over 650 established visual art, design and fine craft professionals include architects, landscape architects, painters, printmakers, photographers, book artists, graphic designers, industrial designers, interior designers, fashion designers, textile artists, ceramicists, sculptors, performance artists, installation artists, filmmakers, videographers, animators, type designers, metalsmiths, media artists and more.

INDIEGOGO FUNDRAISER ARTISTS

Josée Dubeau: http://www.joseedubeau.com/index.php?/publicati...

Thaddeus Holownia: https://holownia.com

Marie-Jeanne Musiol: https://laforetradieuse.com

Naoko Matsubara: http://naokomatsubara.com/home.html

Robert Tombs: http://www.roberttombs.com

Andrew Wright: http://www.andrewwright.ca 

Royal Canadian Academy of Arts: https://rca-arc.ca

Other Ways You Can Help

You might also consider making a donation to our trip through our endowment hosted by the Ottawa Community Foundation

https://www.ocf-fco.ca/funds/en-royal-canadian-...

At the bottom of the page, please select "Flow-through: donations can be granted immediately." By this means, funds can be directed to our Sweden trip directly.
story_txt:
Objekt—a reading room
WHY NOT SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN ON YOUR SOCIAL MEDIA NETWORK?
Please help fund the Royal Canadian Academy of Arts' exhibition Objekt—a reading room * at SUPERMARKET 2021: Stockholm Independent Art Fair, Stockholm, Sweden, October 13–17, 2021. Objekt will be a reading room where art fair attendees can freely peruse bookworks by 32 contemporary Canadian artists. You donation will enable two artist-hosts, Josée Dubeau, RCA and Robert Tombs, RCA, to travel with the exhibition components, and to set up and present the exhibition over five days.
These bookworks contain text and image such as were determined by our selection of artists, designers, craftspersons, essayists and publishers. Confirmed participating artists are Diane Leclair Bisson, Deanna Bowen, Jane Buyers, Ginette Caron, Amanda Dawn Christie, Sorel Cohen, Christos Dikeakos, Josée Dubeau, Pnina C. Gagnon, Adrian Göllner, Jerry Grey, Wesley Harris, Lucy Hogg, Thaddeus Holownia, Geoffrey James, Peter Krausz, Guy Lavigueur, Naoko Matsubara, Gordon Monahan, Robert Murray, Marie-Jeanne Musiol, Leslie Reid, Marina Roy, John A. Schweitzer, Nick Shinn, Michael Snow, Alan Stein, Penelope Stewart, Robert Tombs, Henk van Assen, George Weber, Andrew Wright and Jinny Yu. Additionally, Robert Tombs will give a presentation on artist's books, and Objekt participant Gordon Monahan, a 2012 Governor General's Visiual And Media Arts laureate, will present the sound performance Boiling Water.
The city of Stockholm stands on fourteen islands on Sweden's south-central east coast. According to legend, the city's name tells you how it was born: as a fortress made of logs ('stock') on an island ('holm') guarding the entrance to Lake Mälaren. Stockholm has been Sweden's political, cultural and economic center since the 1200s. SUPERMARKET 2021 will be held at Stadsgårdsterminalen, a former cruise ship terminal in Stockholm harbour, from October 13 to 17, 2021. SUPERMARKET has been presented in Stockholm since 2007 by a small group of 'kulture vultures', most of whom are artists. It is an evolution of Minimarket, which was first held at Konstnärshuset in 2006. Over the years SUPERMARKET has grown into the biggest art fair in the Nordic countries featuring hundreds of artists from all over the world.
*'Objekt' is the Swedish spelling for 'object', and a curatorial conceit for the physical book as it occupies space in the world.

What We Need & What You Get
We need to raise $2085 to complete our budget. A selection of books are proposed here, donated by the artists, as suitable additions to any library, each one a living document from Canada's contemporary art and design scene. Why not add a book from Objekt—a reading room to your library and help us get to Stockholm?

The Impact
Canada is a long way from the galleries, artist-run centres and performance venues of Europe, South America and Asia. By cost-effectively promoting 32 artists in one event, we are creating an extended conversation that will certainly advance the careers of a number of Canadian artists.

Our earliest members include painter Lucius R. O’Brien, first President of the RCA, and architect/painter Napoléon Bourassa, first Vice-President. Distinguished Academicians have since included painters Marcel Barbeau, Ghitta Caiserman-Roth, Marcelle Ferron, Clarence Gagnon, Yves Gaucher, Betty Goodwin, Lawren P. Harris, Gershon Iskovitz, Garry Neill Kennedy, Daphne Odjig, Mary Pratt, Marc-Aurèle de Foy Suzor-Coté and Frederick Varley; filmmakers Paul Almond, Evelyn Lambart and Norman McLaren; architects Charles P. Baillargé, Guy Desbarats, Arthur Erickson and John C. Parkin; photographers Lynne Cohen, Samuel Tata and Yousuf Karsh; printmakers Kenojuak Ashevak and Pitseolak Ashoona; sculptor Kiugak Ashoona; silversmith Lois Etherington Betteridge; ceramicist Erica Deichman Gregg; and performance artist Colette Urban.
Today’s RCA is committed to assuring a diversity of members and artistic disciplines. Our over 650 established visual art, design and fine craft professionals include architects, landscape architects, painters, printmakers, photographers, book artists, graphic designers, industrial designers, interior designers, fashion designers, textile artists, ceramicists, sculptors, performance artists, installation artists, filmmakers, videographers, animators, type designers, metalsmiths, media artists and more.
INDIEGOGO FUNDRAISER ARTISTS

Thaddeus Holownia: https://holownia.com
Marie-Jeanne Musiol: https://laforetradieuse.com
Naoko Matsubara: http://naokomatsubara.com/home.html
Robert Tombs: http://www.roberttombs.com
Andrew Wright: http://www.andrewwright.ca 
Royal Canadian Academy of Arts: https://rca-arc.ca

Other Ways You Can Help
You might also consider making a donation to our trip through our endowment hosted by the Ottawa Community Foundation
https://www.ocf-fco.ca/funds/en-royal-canadian-...
At the bottom of the page, please select "Flow-through: donations can be granted immediately." By this means, funds can be directed to our Sweden trip directly.

story:
Short Summary

We are an eclectic group of ten contemporary artists trying to put on the best possible show we can! This is our final year in the Masters of Fine Arts program at the University of South Florida in Tampa, Florida. On April 3rd, 2020 we will open our final exhibition at the Contemporary Art Museum in Tampa. We are asking for your help to produce a professional catalog to accompany our exhibition. The catalog will include images from, and essays about, each of the artists in the exhibition.

Featured Artists:

Mahya Amini, Rachel Underwood, Jon Notwick, Jenal Dolson, Jezebeth Roca Gonzalez, Matt Campbell, Rhonda Donovan, Mohsen Azar, Ashley Lester, Kyle Timberman

Special thanks to the USF Master of Art History students. 

This catalog features the writing of the MA's who have been paired with each of the graduating MFA's.  Individual essays have been written on each artist accompanied by images of their most recent works.

A true collaborative effort that has been in the making all year... 

 

What We Need & What You Get:

  • We are asking for $2000 to produce a professional-quality catalog for our exhibition. We need anywhere between 3 and 5 thousand dollars to produce our catalog. Through various fundraisers and with the help of some generous organizations we are most of the way there. We need your help to put us over the top. 
  • The funds we raise will go to the printing and distribution of our exhibition catalog. Any extra fund will be distributed among the group for art supplies and materials.
  • Your contributions will get you anything from catalogs to unique pieces of artwork from the members of our cohort.

Image: Ashley Lester

Risks & Challenges

There are a few risks with this project but we have already raised a considerable amount of funds ourselves. We are asking you to help meet our goal AND put us over the top!!!

Image: Jon Notwick

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this project with all of your friends on social media and come see our exhibition on

April 3rd, 2020

Exhibition Open 7-10pm

 

 

Image: Jenal Dolson

 

 

Image: Rachel Underwood

 

 

The CAM at USF

story:
What is the project?

 

This is a national community arts project that will creatively link charities responding to addiction or homelessness in Manchester, Bristol, Canterbury, Newcastle and Birmingham.

 

 

The Political History of Smack and Crack is a theatre show inspired by the writer’s own experience in jail and rehab. It is an epic love-song to a lost generation following Neil and Mandy through the heroin epidemic of the Thatcher years.

After the riots of 1981, smack, and in its wake crack, became rife in urban areas, enchanting both the vulnerable and the disillusioned through both addiction and crime. This echoes even now with people affected still accessing support from charities across the country such as the Mustard Tree and the Men’s Room in Manchester, Bristol Drug Project, SIFA Fireside in Birmingham, Catching Lives in Canterbury and Skylight Crisis in Newcastle.

I’ve been working with all these charities over the last few months to develop a project to creatively link service users at these charities in remembering the riots of 1981 through a national art project. Especially as we now approach its 40-year anniversary next year.

Art workshops will take place at these charities and participating service users will be supported to co-create a new artwork, which will be influenced by the themes and content of The Political History of Smack and Crack.

Written by Ed Edwards, this acclaimed production is about two long-term addicts charting their lives from the Moss Side riots in 1981 through the heroin epidemic that followed to the present day in Manchester. The show will be on a national tour between 21st January and 22nd February.

Using The Political History of Smack and Crack as inspiration, participants will create their own artistic response to these issues on an A5 Art Tile. Throughout the tour, more and more Art Tiles will be created and the collection will be displayed in each theatre venue as a collage of individual responses that make up the whole artwork and the participants will be invited to see the play for free.

Once the tour is over, the artworks we will make digital copies of the Art Tiles. The original Art Tiles will be returned to the artists and, if we raise enough money, we will produce high-quality prints of the whole collection which will be gifted to each participating charity for exhibition.

 

 

What We Need

We have already secured Arts Council funding for the touring production and we are asking for your support to reach our £1300 target so that we can achieve the ambition of this national community arts project.

We will incur the following costs, which we are asking for your help towards:

£175 fee for the work of experienced facilitators in each of the 4 participating locations

£60 for the materials used at each of these workshop including the blank Art Tiles

£500 for the scanning of the original artworks and printing of high-quality prints

 

The Impact

Why are we doing this?

In 2018, The Political History of Smack and Crack performed for 13 nights at the charity Mustard Tree in Manchester, who have been combating poverty and preventing homelessness across Greater Manchester since 1994. These performances were part of the International Arts and Homelessness Festival curated by With One Voice.

 

During these performances, the play connected with many people who had experience of homelessness and related drug dependency issues; people who rarely see their experiences represented on stage in an accessible way. We also provided numerous opportunities for creative community engagement during that time, including writing sessions, drama workshops and performance opportunities. The response to this from participants was fantastic!

Remounting the play for a national tour, we felt it was imperative to work with Mustard Tree again to support their vital work and we wanted to develop a new creative project that partnered the play. With the production touring the UK, we felt it was a great opportunity to connect with other organisations like Mustard Tree in other cities.

We are delivering this national arts project in order to engage with more people with experience of the play’s issues. We want to provide opportunities for creative expression and have that proudly exhibited in major venues alongside people with similar experiences.

 

Risks & Challenges

We have already raised much of the funding from other sources such as an Arts Council England grant. Everything has been fully costed and budgeted.

We have identified and engaged with amazing facilitators in each location to support the delivery of this work and ensure the wellbeing of all participants. We have ensured that each facilitator has ample experience of working with vulnerable adults as well as a passion for this particular project.

Additionally, we are working closely with each of the participating charities to encourage their clients to be involved, support the project in the workshop and ensure the participants' wellbeing. The charities involved are all very well established and have a track record of delivering creative programmes for their clients. The charities include:

Bristol Drug Project

Catching Lives, Canterbury

SIFA Fireside, Birmingham

Crisis Skylight, Newcastle

Mustard Tree, Manchester

story:
A Gorgeous Calendar for a Great Cause

The "Cystic FibRoses" 2019 calendar is a collaborative project by ten artists to support people who live with cystic fibrosis. Each artist has contributed their unique style to the calendar, with mediums ranging from film photography and digital art to watercolor and wool painting. While each piece is unique, they all share roses as a central theme. This one-of-a-kind calendar is only available through this fundraiser, which supports the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation in their search for a cure.

Cystic Fibrosis and the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation

Cystic fibrosis is a life-shortening genetic disease that affects more than 70,000 people worldwide. When a person has two mutated copies of the CFTR gene, the mucus in their lungs and digestive system becomes very thick and sticky. This mucus creates a perfect breeding ground for bacteria in the lungs, causing chronic infections and permanent lung damage. The thick mucus can also make it more difficult for the body to absorb nutrients, leading to malnutrition and problems gaining weight. Over time, cystic fibrosis can impact the liver, the pancreas, bone density, fertility, and much more.

The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation is the leading nonprofit organization that supports people with cystic fibrosis and their families in the United States. Their mission statement is “to cure cystic fibrosis and to provide all people with the disease the opportunity to lead full, productive lives by funding research and drug development, promoting individualized treatment, and ensuring access to high-quality, specialized care.” The life expectancy of people born with cystic fibrosis has doubled in the past thirty years, in large part due to the work of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. Your contribution to this fundraiser will directly improve the quality of life of people living with cystic fibrosis and support the search for a life-saving cure.

If you would like to learn more about cystic fibrosis and the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, you may visit their website at www.cff.org.

Budget Breakdown

For each $30 contribution, approximately $14-$17 will be donated to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation; the exact amount depends on several factors, which are explained below. The rest of the money will be spent on three major expenses: printing the calendar, paying IndieGoGo platform and credit card fees, and paying the artists who created the calendar. (Shipping costs are charged separately so that more money from each contribution can be donated.)

The calendars will be professionally printed by Smartpress on 100# glossy paper, and the pages will be saddle stitched together for a smooth look. The cost per calendar will depend on how many donations we receive: the more calendars we order, the cheaper each calendar will be to print.

Sample Printing Costs
Number of Calendars Ordered 25 50 100 200
Printing Cost per Calendar $7.87 $6.44 $5.48 $4.23

 

IndieGoGo charges a 5% platform fee on all money raised through their website, including shipping charges. In addition, credit card transactions will have a 3% plus $0.30 fee. For orders of one calendar placed within the United States, this amounts to $3.34; orders for multiple calendars and orders placed outside the United States may incur additional fees.

The artists spent many hours bringing this calendar to life, and I strongly believe that they deserve to be paid for their time and effort. Therefore, they will each receive $0.50 per calendar sold ($5 total per calendar). Many of them have chosen to donate their earnings to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation as well; however, these donations are completely voluntary and are not counted as part of the estimated $14-$17 donation per calendar.

The Creative Team

My name is Cameron Gaebler, and I am the parent of a child with cystic fibrosis. My daughter's diagnosis took me by surprise, and while it has definitely brought its fair share of challenges, it has also led me to a thriving online community I otherwise never would have found: the community of people who live with cystic fibrosis and the people who love them. Their support in the early days of my daughter's diagnosis inspired me to give back to the community, and so the “Cystic FibRoses” calendar was born. As my daughter grows up, I hope to inspire her to likewise give back to her communities in ways both big and small.

I am the behind-the-scenes organizer who coordinates the creative team's efforts and manages the logistics of the fundraiser. Although I contributed one piece of art to the calendar, this project would not have been possible without the support of ten other amazing artists. Their names and contact information (where applicable) are listed below.

Shana Anderson: www.facebook.com/MoonDogWoolies
Nicolas Carjuzâa
Curious Cuttlefisch: www.frostfeather.net
Alex Fairfortune: alex.fairfortune@gmail.com
Carl Grasso: carlmgrasso@gmail.com
Evan Hughes: www.deepeningwoods.net
Robert Michaud: robert.j.michaud@gmail.com
John Shrader: www.instagram.com/albinogoth
Nathan Tripp
Jan Whalen: jnjwhalen@gmail.com

From the entire creative team behind the "Cystic FibRoses" 2019 calendar, thank you for joining us in this project. Your donation supports people living with cystic fibrosis today and brings us closer to a cure tomorrow.

FAQs

Where do you ship? How much does shipping cost?

Calendars can be shipped to any country served by the United States Post Office Priority Mail service (more than 180 countries worldwide). Shipping will cost $8 to any address within the United States and $35 to all other countries.

Can you ship my calendars to multiple addresses?

No. If you would like to send calendars to multiple locations, please make one donation for each address.

Can I pick up my calendars in person?

If you know me personally and would like to pick up your calendar in person rather than pay for shipping, please contact us at cfrosescalendar@gmail.com to make arrangements. In your email, please include your name, how many copies of the calendar you would like to purchase, and where we can meet for you to pick up your calendar.

How do I order in bulk?

If you would like to order more than five calendars, please contact us at cfrosescalendar@gmail.com so we can make arrangements for shipping your calendars.

Are purchases tax deductible?

Although the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation is a 501(c)(3) charity, purchases of the "Cystic FibRoses" calendar made through IndieGoGo are NOT tax-deductible. You will receive a receipt from IndieGoGo rather than the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. If you plan on itemizing your taxes and would like to deduct a portion of this purchase from your taxes, please contact us at cfrosescalendar@gmail.com to make arrangements.

When will my calendar be delivered?

I will do my very best to deliver the calendars by mid-December 2018. I have worked with the printer to ensure that the calendars will be delivered to me with plenty of time to process your orders. However, sometimes unexpected events derail even the best plans, especially when you are raising a toddler with complex medical needs! While I cannot guarantee that you will receive your calendar in time for the holidays, I do promise to send regular updates and inform you of any delays immediately.

Is this fundraiser officially connected to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation?

No, this fundraiser is not officially connected to or endorsed by the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. All money raised will go directly to me. I will use these funds to reimburse myself for the production costs of the calendars and to pay the artists, then donate the profits to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation in December 2018. I will share the receipt from the donation with all backers for accountability and transparency.

What if I want to donate more money to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation?

Thank you for your generosity! If you would like to make an extra donation to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, please do so at www.cff.org/Get-Involved/Donate/Make-a-Donation. (If you are not already connected to a CFF chapter, please select the Los Angeles chapter on the donation page.) Making the donation directly has two benefits: your donation will be tax-deductible, and 100% of your donation will go to the organization (rather than IndieGoGo fees).

How can I help, other than by purchasing a calendar?

Help us spread the word about this fundraiser! You can follow and share our Facebook page (fb.me/cfrosescalendar), print out a flyer to hang at your school or workplace (goo.gl/F1284R), and (the best approach of all) personally reach out to people who you think would love this calendar and this cause and invite them to order a calendar.

Does the calendar include any holidays or other days of interest?

No. To make the calendar equally appealing to an international audience, we chose not to print them with any national holidays, religious holidays, or other days of interest. However, orders shipping within the United States will include a list of federal holidays in 2019 so that you can easily write them in yourself if desired.

Why did you choose roses as the theme for the calendar?

To learn more about the connection between roses and cystic fibrosis, visit www.cff.org/About-Us/About-the-Cystic-Fibrosis-Foundation/The-65-Roses-Story.
